Pours a really dark reddish/brown with a huge fluffy brown head. Lots of toasted malt and caramel on the nose, dark fruits, toffee, milk chocolate and a light bready note. Lots of bold roasted coffee and chocolate on the taste, caramel, some dark fruits, toasted malt, and a little boozy. Medium bodied. Really well balanced, and a great example of the style.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2013 Poured from a bottle into snifter. Dark black brown pour with a big chalky brown head that takes off quickly without much lacing. Aroma is some malt, pretzel and bread up front; sweet cereal and a bit of chocolate. more carbonation than expected up front, quick and chocolate sweet up front that evolves into a roasted coffee malty finish.

Pours dark black with a healthy tan head. Aroma is roast, chalk, dark fruit, and toasted malt. The taste is chocolate, roast, soy sauce, light berries, and oak. Medium body with medium to high carbonation.

Bottle( kindly donated by ThirsyBird!):Almost black, stable tanned foamy layer, traces of leather, wood and sweet dried fruits in the solid malty to caramelly nose; quite solid sweet-bitter flavour, full bodied and smooth; increasing dryness in fruity, but mainly bitter-toasty finish. A perfectly balanced Baltic Porter

650 mL bottle purchased from Top Shelf Brews yesterday afternoon for $6.49. What a deal! 2013 release. Although it doesnt have it listed anywhere on the label, I believe it clocked in at about 9.4% abv.  To undersized snifter, it pours an oaken, charcoal dark brown with a general  Limonite ochre-painted head, half a fingernail in length.  Smells gloriously of fennel seeds, almond butter, char, American Spirit tobacco, milk chocolate, peanut paste, marsh rosemary, crystallized ginger, candi sugar, burnt hay, and toffee.This stuff is wonderful, pure and simple. Tastes like a southern spicy BBQ where hotties show up just to dance. Nice.
Draft to pint. Looks good; black with sticky beige lacing. Smells and tastes solid; dark malt and chocolate with a touch of roast. Nice and smooth on the palate. A good example of the style.

2009 vintage. Pours deep dark black/brown with brown head.  Smell is deep  roasted malt, chocolate, licorice. Taste is as it smells - very tasty stuff. Full bodied and nicely carbonated. Well a world class beer.

Pitch black. Caramelized sugar, dark roasted coffee, mellow smoke, bitter chocolate, and a touch of raisin-like fruitiness at the end. Smooth with a medium-to-heavy body. Delicious. An exceptional example of the style.

Deep brown to black pour with a tan head. The aroma has a lot of chocolate and roasted malt notes, exactly like I want in a porter. The flavor is more of the same. The chocolate and roasted notes go very well together and are complimented by a bit of dark fruit and a little bit of alcohol. Medium to thick mouthfeel and medium carbonation

Poured from 22oz bomber, pours pitch black with a nice light brown head and lacing, aroma has a nice amount of tabbaco mixed in with a little dark fruit and chocolate, flavor has a sweet front end with some chocolate and tobacco in the finish, really earthy and full, shelf wale bros.
Roasted malt.  Bit of chocolate. Has a bit of that porter malt which is very slight but this is still fresh.  Tasty stuff maybe a bit overrated.

Dark brown, medium large tan head.  Aroma roasted malts, licorice, raisins.  Medium full body.  Alcohol not overly present.  Sweet but not too sweet malt flavors, mildly roasted, with some dates and figs, caramel.  Nice.

Enjoyed this beer alot. It was very hard to locate but I finally found a shop that had it. Was very excited to try. The high alcohol content surprised me initially but once I got over that, it was a delight.
Pours black with a nice half inch head that lasts and has nice lacing. Full body with medium bitterness, smooth, average carbonation and a long finish. Excellent.
One of my favorite all around Porters, too bad its seasonal. Dark, malty, good balance of hops
Pour was very dark.  Aroma was full of roasted malty goodness.  Flavor was full of dark and rich malt flavors with a nice hop punch at the end.  It was a bit boozy also.
Strong smell of licorice any other stuff.  Higher carbonation - but a great beer.  Go New Hampshire!

Poured from a 22 ounce bottle thanks to weihenweizen. Thanks! Pours a darker brown to black with a nice cap of khaki colored foam. The aroma has a lot of coffee and roasty, bready, chocolatey malt. Very smooth coffee and roast come through in the taste. This beer is great!

2012. Bomber. Pours near enough to black. Cant quite see through the beautiful, persistent tan head. Nice sheeting. Nose of roasted malts, vanilla, coffee, bittersweet chocolate. Taste is a smooth blend of the same, not overly sweet, not overly roasted, low enough ABV for any offensive burn. Wow. This is great.

2010 bottle. 
Aroma has some roast and chocolate but also has quite a bit of vinous dark fruit to the aroma and some sherry aromas. The dark fruit is mostly prune but also a hint of raisin. Low alcohol aroma, but it is present. 
Pours black with hints of brown on the edges. A thick light mocha head that steadily recedes. Very faint lacing and mid sized legs. 
Flavor hits right away with sweet milk chocolate. There are secondary roast notes with hints of coffee and tobacco. The fruit esters are lighter in the flavor but there is still some prune and raisin in the finish. Low astringency and medium bitterness. Light alcohol bite in the finish. 
Mouthfeel is medium full to full bodied with quite a bit of creaminess to it. The astringency is low but present and the alcohol warmth is medium to medium high. 
Overall this is a very enjoyable Baltic porter though possibly not to style. The roast character isn't as strong as I would expect and instead its got tons of chocolate. This beer probably has reached the max of how long it can safely be aged. I'm not sure it could handle another year without becoming a sherry bomb. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle.  Pours dark brown with a small sudsy tan head.  Nose is roasted malt, cocoa, light coffee, and dark fruits.  Similar flavor, slightly creamy palate.  Nice beer.
From a 22 oz bottle shared at home.  Pours black head with a tan.  Roasted malt aroma.  Coffee and chocolate notes smooth and astringent.  Nice porter.

Bottle. Pours a dark black color with a decent tan head. Roasted malt notes with some caramel and vanilla in the background. Complex taste. Strong vanilla notes with brown sugar. Very smooth and not overpowering. Overall, a really solid porter.

22oz bottle. Pours a clear dark brown / red color, with a good brown head. Head slowly fizzes away. Decent loose lace. Bigger body, lighter carbonation, good chewier texture. Nice chocolate, dark fruit, and earthy flavors. Nice bittersweet taste. Was fantastic to enjoy with a sandwich. On its own though, was a bit heavy. Cool imperial porter, though

Aroma is coffee, pipe tobacco, raisins, and brown bread.  Flavor starts malty, with coffee, chocolate, and dark fruit.  Roast coffee bitterness and alcohol in a very dry finish.  They promised big and bold, and they delivered.
22 ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Pembroke Pines, FL for $3.99 Very good, great price!

Vintage 2009, Enjoyed September 2012.  22 oz. bottle poured into a goblet. 8.7% abv.

Appearance:  Pours a viscous dark brown with frothy tan edges.

Aroma:  Roasted malt, dark fruit, wood, vanilla, smoke.

Taste:  Roasted smokey malt, dark chocolate, wood, burnt roast. Long bitter chocolate finish.

Mouthfeel: Full bodied lively bubbles.

Overall: One of the few occasions where Ive enjoyed a beer cellared more rather than fresh. This beer could probably hold up another two years without a blink. Tasty, roasty, complex, chocolaty but not sweet. Great job.

Thanks Aaron, finally. Pours dark and black with a small tan head. Nose is big coffee, nutty, grassy and chocolate. Taste is sweet, slightly tart, true to the style with excellent bitter aftertaste. Mouthfeel is silly smooth and creamy yet has some pop to it. Body is heavy and finish is decadent. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Deep black body, moderate sized medium brown head, spotty, soapy lacing.  Nose is caramel, coffee, roast, dark fruits and a little chocolate.  Flavor is more pronounced with warm caramel, roasted coffee, bittersweet chocolate, and some raisins.  Full bodied, moderate carbonation, light bitterness in the finish.

Bottle poured a deep black with a huge tan head and excellent lacing.  Aroma is big on dark fruit, roasted malt, and coffee beans.  Taste begins with an enjoyable smoked flavor followed by cocoa, bakers chocolate, and roasted malt.  Wonderful mouthfeel with each sip beginning creamy and leaving a nice sticky coating.  Very enjoyable porter.

About 6 oz. (from a 22 oz. bomber) poured into a small wine glass. From notes.

A: Pours a very dark brown color body. The head is a three finger light tan color with impressive retention and lacing.

S: Strong roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, and dark fruit - a textbook smell, but a great one.

T: This has one of the most immensely bold roast profiles Ive ever encountered; actually this is one of the most in your face tasting beers Ive ever had. The huge roastiness does transition to chocolate and licorice after a while, while the finish sees a surge of dark fruit to go with the big roast. Wow, this has so much flavor, and it has solid balance, to boot.

M: This has a medium body with good carbonation and dryness. The aftertaste is loaded with long-lasting dark fruit and roast, and the alcohol isnt very noticeable on the palate and body.

O: Heres the thing. Its amazingly flavorful, but theres so much flavor that it hinders its drinkability somewhat. Put simply, its an incredible beer that makes me unsure I could polish off a bomber of it solo. Split this one with friends, a little goes a long, long, LONG way. Id still get this stuff again and again without hesitation.
My favorite Baltic porter.  Slight raisin and dark fruits.  Perfect mouthfeel.  Very slight bitterness in the end.  The is a great beer and I would recommend experimenting with aging.

Pours a nearly opaque dark brown with a nice small bead espresso foam head.  Aroma is also espresso.  Taste is a combination of delicious roasted malts lending a coffee and cocoa character.  Very smooth; little to no bitterness.  A quality porter.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2013 Pours a cola black with a big head and smells like a mingling of beer, saltwater and sweet, rich coffee.  The taste is outstanding.  There isnt a lot of taste up front, but at the swallow theres this slightly bitter bite that gives way to this amazing, warm, rich, strong chocolate malt finish.  Each drink coated my mouth and faded slowly, leaving that rich malt to linger behind it.  This was delicious.

A - pours deep rich coffee brown with high fast disappearing fluffy chocolate head. S - strong aromas rich chocolate and dark dried fruits. Reminiscent of a chocolate covered raisins. Smokey and chalky. Hints of bitter burned toffee. M - full bodied bitter brew with a nice sweet lingering touch on the lips. Dry and bitter up front, soft alcohol warming on the end. Light medicine on the end. T - bitter coffee, toasted toffee, dry and bitter front. Dark dried fruit and chocolate lie on the palate. Lingering dry bitter medicine undertones and burned malts. O - very good strong full bodied porter. 8

09 vintage, shared with dasilky1.  Pours a dark brown/black with a tan head. Aromas of burnt sugar, liquorish, bitter dark chocolate. Taste is similar; dry smokiness, some charred elements, raisins, muted rum cake and dark fruit. If I didnt know better, Id say this was oak aged. Average carbonation. Very dry, slight warming finish. Decent.

2009 Bottle from tap & mallet, rochester.  Dark pour with a solid tan sheet of suds.  Nose of burnt sugar, licorice, & a little chocolate in the somewhat nicely robust nose.  Some smokey notes as well.  Carbonation is very soft, showing up mainly at the end.  Thick too, carrying firm malty sensations, chocolate and smoke, some licorice too, and robust raisin notes and chocolate covered dark fruits. Has held up considerably well over the 3 years...remaining loaded with malty flavors and thick, somewhat chewy body...even still remotely hoppy in the finish to balance it all out.  Quite nice.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2012 2012 Bottle Date; Sampled August 2012
The beer pours into my Lost Abbey Teku glass with a four finger thick, brown tinged, concentrated tan colored head that leaves lots of lacing as it settles. The beer is a simple, opaque, black color. A huge cocoa liquor aroma jumps out of the glass and is joined by sweet coffee notes, a slightly chalky character (though definitely in a good way), roasted burnt nutty notes, burnt brown sugar aromatics, an almost rum like character, as well as an oaky character somehow, and even notes that remind me of burnt brandy somehow. There is also a huge, toasted / roasted whole grain character to the nose.

The beer tastes sweet, but not cloying as it is easily balanced by lots of roasted character. Bitter roast notes mix with bitter hop notes in the finish. This has a huge, smooth, cocoa / dark chocolate character to it in the flavor, as well as notes of coffee liquor, and lots of roasted nutty notes. The body is much lighter than the robust flavor would suggest; this is not overly light in character, as it still has some heft to it as well as some viscousnous. This has really nice roast profile, it is quite smooth though, but certainly pronounced; the combination of bitter, burnt, and roast really defines the profile.

This is really nice, it is much better than I expected, and it is a very enjoyable surprise. Definitely dont dump in the sediment from the bottom of the bottle, it makes the beer hot and alcohol expressive; luckily I didnt sully my clean pour with the sediment. Simply awesome.
Pours a black brown color with a large light brown head. Notes of coffee, booze, smoke, Oreo cookie, and dirt. Pretty good.
Dark brown color with a thick tan head. Very thick creamy mouth feel. Sweet start with coffee and chocolate notes. The finish is slightly bitter, and burnt. The finish brought the rating down.

2009 bottle, bomber, cellared for 3 years. Big nose of chocolate, soy, bonito flakes, some coffee and port. Rich, smooth flavor, rather smoky, with umami and some wood, chocolate. Very sweet but well balanced by roasted malts and some alcohol. Very well integrated after three years, and super smooth. great.

Pours a thick black color almost like used motor oil with dark tan lacing.  A massive amount of rich dark chocolate on the nose. The palate has a fireside chocolate feel. This is a great beer and a perfect example of the style. Warms you up in so many ways.

Bomber. Pours dark dark brown with a great bubbly brown head. Aroma is spicy sweet peppery roasted fruity pears tobacco cLoffee. Flavor is velvety fruity acidy roasted in front with more fruity pear sweetness and bitterness from middle with tones of coffee and tobacco evolving to more chocolaty cocoa bitterness with the acidity from the beginning turning into a tounge tingling sensation. Finishes longlived roasted and bitter. Well balanced and extremely flavorfull.

(Bottle) Pours black with a brown head. The aroma is fruity and roasted with notes of pear liqueur, plums, raisins, apple tobacco, roasted grain, dark bread, burned caramel and coffee. Touch of alcohol and hops. The flavour is light to medium sweet, medium bitter and tiny acidic with notes of roasted grain, dark bread, coffee, caramel, raisins, figs, plums and tobacco. Earthy, grassy, woodsy and light citric hops. The mouthfeel is, smooth, velvety and tiny tart with a light, soft carbonation. fruity cocoa, robust malt and hops on the finish. Medium bodied.

Man these guys can run the spectrum of beers.  Just had a couple atrocities by smuttynose and then I pour this beer.  Absolutely fantastic baltic porter.  Very rich and roasty with slight dark fruit notes and chocolate.  Really flavorful and well done.  If I could use a baseball analogy for this brewery it would be Mark Reynolds, they close their eyes and swing really hard and sometimes they make contact.  This was that rare HR.

poured from bomber into a tulip. Pours a near black color with a small head.

Deep deep aromas of coffee, roasted malts, and bitter dark chocolate.

Full bodied with a real rich feel and really good notes of roasted coffee, malts, and dark chocolate.

This was damn good. A big beer that really packs a wallop.

Une robe brune, presque noire.  Un petit col de mousse.  Un nez de chocolat au lait et de notes rôtis.  Une fumée latente et une explosion de raisins.  Des saveurs rôtis et assez costaudes.  Une étendue des fruits qui se donnent à cur joie sur mes papilles.  De bons grains torréfiés encore fumants.  Une bouche de belle facture.  Un corps assez rond et un pétillement posé.  Une texture crémeuse.  Une finale de grains torréfiés aux notes amères peu intenses. Excellente dégustation avec Yan et madame sa femme.
Damn, yo. This pours dark and thick and has a moderate brown head to it. This definitely has some coffee notes to it. A great porter...

Style et résumé: Baltic Porter de bonne facture.  
Comment: Bomber partagé par Patrick sur les rives de sa piscine. 
Description: Porter brun très foncé avec une mousse tout aussi brune et un anneau de durable. Il me semble que le nez est très fruité avec beaucoup de cerises et de café. La bouche est fraiche, rafraichissante, les saveurs sont sur de notes de café, de fruits secs et frais. Lalcool est bien dissimulé et discret. Franchement un bon produit dune surprenante fraicheur. 
Note:  7+/10

Poured from a 22oz bottle into a goblet. Quite dark, half inch of tan head. Looks beautiful.

Just holding my nose over it I get some caramel, once I breath in it is roasted malt and cocoa.

Noticeable alcohol taste. Malty all over. Roasted and a bit of burned malt taste.

Oh wow. Smooth and creamy with almost no carbonation at first and then just a light amount at the end.

Practically perfect. A great balance of flavor and BIG BEERness to make this a fireside sipper or a more regular drink.

Pours black with a very thin brown head. Nose is deep roasted malt with notes of bittersweet cocoa and charcoal. Flavor is roasted malts, sweet chocolate and some dark fruits. Very rich mouthfeel and has some hop bitterness at the end. Great beer.
Pours pitch black with brown head.  Aroma is raisins, dark chocolate, prunes.  Taste is dark fruits, coffee, dark chocolate, pretty strong on the booze as well.  Palate is thick.  I like it a lot.

This is the second round with this jewel and I must say it is better this time.  Beautiful nose full of caramel, smoke, and peppery hops.  The nutmeg cap on the dark, dense pour fades slowly and leaves a sticky lacing on the snifter.  Sweet up front followed by rich coffee sweetened by molasses with some charred oak  and pepper on the finish.  This brew pairs well with Musorgsky  cranked to about nine on the hi-fi!

Bottle from Total Wines Ft Lauderdale. It pours jet black, with a thin tan head. The nose is roasted malt, caramel, chocolate, leather and dark fruit. The taste is roasted malt, charcoal, ash, acidic coffee, dark chocolate and alcohol warmth with a dry-roasted finish. Medium-full body, fine carbonation and sticky mouth-feel. Pretty hot and rough around the edges. A bit of a disappointment.

Bottle. Pours clear black with a large (perhaps a bit too large) frothy brown head that lasts a long time and has excellent lacing. Aroma is heavy on roasted malt and coffee, with chocolate notes and a bit of spice included. Flavor is medium sweet, coffee, roasted malt, coffee and chocolate, with an unidentified spiciness. Medium bitter finish. Rich and creamy in the mouth.

Smells of oiled leather, dark molassess, dark cocoa.  Strong alcohol in nose.   Pitch black with thick tan head.  Taste sarts bitter and alcoholic but quickly sweetens. Nose is reinforced in taste but some tobacco notes as well.  Mouthfeel is very oily.  Some heat from the alcohol.  Very complex but just too much of everything for my taste.  leaves my palate worn out before finishing the first glass.
Pours black with maybe a finger of head. Smell is full, roasty, bit of cherry. Taste is black licorice, tar, coffee, and a really roasty way down. Pretty good.

Opaque brown-black with dark tan-brown tightly knitted head. 
The commercial description is quite accurate and therefore, worth repeating: 
"Baltic porters are often brewed as lagers, the tradition weve followed. This beer is big, bold & smooth, with malty flavors reminiscent of coffee, dark fruit & raisins. "
And, since 2006,  I thought Anchor Porter would be though to match.
$3.99/22oz bomber @ Total Wine & More, Boca Raton, Florida

Refrigerated bottle poured into a snifter.  Pours black with small medium brown highlight with small beige head that dissapates quickly.  Little lacing, medium body, low carbonation, creamy texture, and light roasted malt aroma.  Taste is roasted malt, dark fruit, burnt coffee, and bitter hop finish.  Alcohol is pretty well covered, pretty good.

Pours black oil,  hot chocolate froth head.  Aroma of mocha and something like almonds or walnuts. Strong malty flavor with very upfront boozy taste.  Thick and chocolaty could almost bite the drink.  Like a stout without the coffee tones, this makes me doubt my love for stouts.  Really satisfying pouring 22 ounces into the biggest glass I have (so what, who doesnt love a huge glass of delicious beer).

650ml bottle. Pours a bruised dark brown with dark beige head of very fine bubbles. Chocolate pudding, boiled fruit and brandy on the nose with a wisp of licorice. Chocolate and licorice dominate the palate with a slight boozy note. Big creamy texture.

Originally reviewed: 1/18/10. Bottle poured into a pint glass. Pours a very thick deep black. Theres a big frothy tan head resting on top. Great retention; left some lace spots on the glass. Scents of roasted malts, sweet cream, and milk chocolate. 

Very creamy body. Carbonation level is low. This is just silky smooth. This is a very sweet Baltic. Mild coffee bitterness present, but this has notes of vanilla, chocolate milk, and a little grape on the finish. This isnt as bold as I expected, but it is still good nonetheless.

brewed in 2010, tasted in 2012. Tan head and has a prune/purple-ish colour in the hue but is a really dark brew. Huge aroma, very welcoming, cake,roast, fruitcake, espresso and a hint of boozy/brandyness. More of the same on the palate, amongst all those roastes and chocolate notes is an acidity that reminds me of something fruity. layered and long finish. Very glad i tried this one.

I dont remember much after drinking this beer. Other then waking up next to Blackhaddock wondering where my breakfast went. I have a faint recollection of coffee beans but disturbingly, they didnt quite help me recover from being knocked unconscious with its bottle. Fine beer as well as rape, has its high and low points:)

Oct 2009: This one pint and six fluid ounce bottle was given to me by Bierman9 (an American BA) in Munich and consummed in my hotel room for breakfast in Nurnberg the next day!

First of all an apology to David, it was drank out of a plastic beaker!

What a fantastic breakfast beer, who needs a coffee and brown toast after one of these?

As mentioned above the beer was poured (about five times) into my plastic toothbrush holder cup and each time it looked great. A dark, deep brown liquid with a dirty creamy head stared straight back at me each time I filled the cup.

My nose detected rich burnt coffee beans, dark chocolate and an Irish Peat Bog in the aroma, a fine mix at nine in the morning.

The taste did justice to the aroma I had been sniffing. Add a slighty smoked Austrian Cheese to the smell mixture. This, along with all the aforementioned robust flavours gave me a wonderful tasting Porter to start the day off with.

I owe David a big one!

Draft at Jerrys. Black with chocolate shake head / Rich, acidic nose of tobacco, coffee, and lemon / Full body, chewy and lightly sweet, with excellent balance and dry finish / Winey, earthy flavors of dark roast coffee, tobacco, chocolate, prunes, lemon, orange, and oak / Superb.  Possibly my best porter ever?

Another great Smuttynose beer. The body was attractive with a black body and huge, tan head. For a porter the earthy scent was light and rather covered with prunes, coffee and chocolate. The taste was full of chocolate and earthy notes, and the finish was like eating fresh coffee beans. Very good, but as it warmed up, the flavors sort of diminished.

Thanks again, Chipalsa. Snifter pour from a bomber. Nose is chocolate, roast, some vanilla, and a bit of coffee. The body is black with a tan colored head, typical of the style. Taste is burnt chocolate with some coffee. It reminded me of a mocha late or something but with less coffee flavor. A great porter.
Bouteille 1 pint 6 oz. Noire opaque avec mousse legere. Nez de cafe, moka et vanille. Bouche genereuse et cremeuse avec du chocolat et du malt roti.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2013 Bottle.  Black, small brown head, solid lacing.  Aroma of smooth milk chocolate melted into a cup of coffee.  Taste is chocolate covered prunes, plums, raisins, coffee grounds.  Very nice.

This poured a pitch black color with a beige head. The aroma contains some dark fruit, coffee, and licorice. A slight smoke presence is also there. The flavor is rather bitter with the coffee really showing up. Some chocolate, licorice, and dark chocolate is also present. The finish has some booze present with more bitterness. Overall a good beer.
Aroma of malt, vanilla, coffee and dark fruit.  Pours black with a perfect tan head.  Taste is.dark and roasty.  Coffee, cocoa, and cane sugar.  Delicious!

Pours black with a 1 finger, soapy tan head that has good retention. Aroam is roast, lots of roasted nuts, toast, smoke, dark fruit, earth and woody notes. Flavor is intensely malty up front, lots of chocolate, roast nuts, chocolate and toast, some smoke, light bitter malts, licorice, sweet bread spice and hints of piney hops. Palate is heavy on entry, syrupy and a little slick, but it seems to lighten and dry up pretty quickly on the palate, but without any astringency, strange, but pleasant. I thoroughly enjoyed this one, big, flavorful, rich and intense, but it cleans up after itself.

Bottle from weis market lewisburg. Pours black with a thick brown head. Lots of raisin on the nose. A bit of caramel on the tongue but lots of raidin as well. Im not getting a ton of malt. Finish lingers a bit. Nice example of style.

Bottle pours thick black with medium brown head.  gFeat lacing.  Aroma malts, roast.  Taste malts and roast with a bit of smoke, chocolate and caramel.  Palate full with slight stickiness.  Finish roast with an alcohol burn.  Alcohol apparent.
Nice Baltic Porter, more roasty than the eastern European BPs but still very solid.
Aroma is malts, coffee and dark fruit.  The flavor is grape/raisin, malts, coffee and acidity/tartness in the finish.  Relatively intense with the grape/raisin flavor, this was very good.

Dark pour with a dark brown head. Aroma is roasted malt and dark fruits. Taste is coffee., roasted malt, slight sweetness/fruits. Very tasty-long lasting flavor that leaves a great aftertaste. The beer clings to the glass. It has legs.

Bottle purchased at Blacklick Wine & Spirits. Pitch black pour with a huge light brown head. Aroma of chocolate, raisin, fig and roasted malt. Flavor starts with chocolate and dark fruit, then moves to a bit of booze before some roasty coffee bitterness, leading to a bitter dark chocolate finish. Full-flavored and delicious.

Pours a deep dark color with a brown head. Strong aroma with hints of coffee and chocolate. Taste is rich and smooth with the hints of coffee and chocolate. Creamy mouthfeel that leads to a dry finish. Very well balanced porter. Not too much of a stretch to say that its one of the better porters Ive had in a while.
Sweet and strong, very roasty. Does not taste remotely like an actual Baltic porter but better. Full bodied, hoppy and rich. A good American stout.

Dark brown/black color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, dark chocolate, & coffee; Flavor of roasted sweet malt, caramel, espresso, dark chocolate, hops, dark fruit, and some licorice; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced & complex; Wow - this is an excellent porter.

Sample at Ale Wine & Spirits in Powell on 02/09/2012. Pours black with a medium tan head that diminishes steadily. Rings of lacing on the glass. Roasted malt and vanilla coffee aroma. Medium to full body with a roasty character and flavors of malt, coffee, vanilla and a bit of dark fruit. The finish is roasted coffee with a hint of hops in the aftertaste. Good all around.

Appearance is exactly what a porter should be,  black with a thick tan head which will last as long as it takes you to drink this beer. Aroma is plentiful with some roasted malts, hints of chocolate, caramel and even some raisin, very slight alcohol smell but not overpowering. Taste is slightly sweet to start but very complex and extremely well balanced. Something for everyone in this; malts, slightly hoppy, chocolate, raisin, coffee but no one flavor stands out. Even ay 9% ABV this is smooth, easy to drink and the 22 oz bomber was gone within the hour.
Pours think and black with a dissipating tan head. Intense nutty aroma. Excellent bitter taste and oily on the palate. One of the better porters Ive had.

Black color with quickly disappearing head, no lacing, overly carbonated, notes of raisin chocolate fig cardboard with slight metallic mouthfeel, good but expected more I actually prefer smuttynose robust porter

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2010 bottle from the basement.....great pour, heavily carbonated, smells sweet.

Very sweet beer, heavy on the malts, tasting coffee, and a sweetness to it, not sure where that is coming from.  ABV well hidden, definitely a big beer, very enjoyable, and well worth the wait.....it was tough to find on the shelf at the time.

Des notes de malt rôti, noix de coco et vanille. En bouche cest soutenu par une sensation de milk stout que les saveurs perçues au nez explosent. Très onctueux avec un déluge de café au final. Buvabilité exceptionnelle pour une si grande bière.

Bomber from Woodmans in the Falls. Pours very dark black - black as night, black as coal - with a brownish-tan head. Some lacing. Aroma brings salty roasted coffee, bittersweet chocolate, some smoke and a hint of lactose. Taste has salty/sweet roasted malts, some bitter coffee, and soy sauce on meat. Quite salty and thick. Finishes with a lot of depth; bittersweet with a tang. I can never figure out the correct temperature for these heavy porters - cold cellar, I guess, as cellar was too warm but refrig needed warming for the flavors to come through.

Draught at Rattle N Hum, NYC, on January 30, 2012Black color, light brown head. Sweet, malty, alcohol taste, some licorice aftertaste, also warming alcohol. Medium to smooth mouthfeel, medium bitterness. Coffee and alcohol scent.

Pint on tap at Kickbacks, Jacksonville.  Black beer with a nice thick brown head.  Chocolate and malt aroma.  Flavor is very sweet, stopped just short of being two sweet, but excellent for a baltic porter.  Very tasty with bold flavors of chocolate, coffee, and dark fruit. Full body and semi-thick mouthfeel.  Very well done, and a delightful desert drink.
Great feel in the mouth with a sweet and fruity beginning that finishes with the dark chocolate and coffee flavor you would expect.

Pours Dark Brown with a foamy brown head with a good amount of lacing left on the glass. It is sweet and malty with a hint of chocolate and a little roast, as well as a touch of Dark fruit, light smoke, faint hint of a hop finish. Medium to full body, Delicious. so far my favorite of the Big Beer Series, although this is only my 3rd one.

22oz bottle from Discount Liquor Milwaukee, split with dwm1034. Pours a jet black color with a thin tan head. Aroma is roasty, chocolate, a little smokey. A little heavy on the palate with soft carbonation. Flavor is bittersweet, chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, with a smooth, bitter coffee finish. Extremely tasty.

It poured a black color with a small light brown head. The aroma was of dark fruits and hints of chocolate and coffee. The taste was of wood and chocolate with a nice subtle bitterness on the finish. This is a very good  brew.

Fairly dark porter with medium mouthfeel and touches of sweetness, fruit, and coffee cocoa flavors. Could use more fruit or smoothness. Comes off a little harsh and a little thin, making it seem just boozy. Not bad, actually good, but I dont see the high rating here.

Bottle. Pours black with a thick tan head. Smells gorgeous of dark fruits, coffee and malt. Tastes slightly fruity tart, mild bitter, and medium sweet. Texture is creamy. Finish is tart. A phenominal beer!

22oz, 2010 bottle. Bought last Xmas, sat in my parents fridge the last year. Split with my Dad. Chocolate, cherries, dark fruits some lactose. Very dark, nearly black with red tinting along the edges. Smallish mocha colored head. Dark chocolate, dark fruits, cappucino. Moderately thick mouthfeel with a very balanced finish and a lingering espresso flavor. Perhaps my favorite of the smuttynose bombers.
This beer is big, bold & smooth, with malty flavors reminiscent of coffee, dark fruit & raisins. Great carbonation levels but not so great after taste

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2016 11/2016.   finished the last of a case of these from a trade with  phatdog1  years ago.  4.4 or 4.5 still one of my faves.  last one had 2-3 years on it; probably only need to age this a year or so................................................ thanks so emacgee for this bomber - HELLYEA!  This just rated out as my mostest favoritest beer ever (will try some yetis to compare).  Big nose of malt, roasts, coffee.  Black pour with frothy tan head; mmmmmm.  perfectly balanced - malts, roasts, dark chocolate powder, and alcohol.  PERFECT balance.  slightly oily, slight fizz.  did I mention that this is GREAT.

PERMANENT want list!!

Bottle split with mcberko. Pours a solid black with a small tan head. Aroma of molasses, vanilla, roasted malts, and dark chocolate. Flavour of lots of molasses and vanilla, roasted malts, dark chocolate, and a hop finish. Full-bodied. Nice.

22 oz. bottle, split 4 ways, pours black with a small tan ring of head. Aroma of vanilla, molasses and chocolate malt. Flavour of vanilla, light roast and molasses. Silky smooth palate, but lacking a bit in complexity. Very good.
UPDATED: DEC 1, 2016 Bottle. Very dark brown with a small tan head. Fruity and malty notes. Coffee, malt, fruit and hops.  Full body with a long, bitter-sweet finish.
Poured from a 22oz bottle.  Pours very dark brown, nearly black.  Aroma is dried fruits and some coffee.  Taste follows the nose with tastes of prunes, soy sauce and some coffee.

(Bottle from Rattle & Hum, NYC).  Ive been on the lookout for this Smuttynose selection for a while.   Rich and intense with lots of malt, coffee, prune and dried fruit.   I look forward to tying again in the heart of the winter.

Bottle.  Pours opaque black with a medium-large, frothy tan head, long retention with excellent lacing.  Aroma is dark chocolate, coffee, roast malt, alcohol, prune, raisins, figs, woody hops, floral and citrus hops with notes of vanilla.  Flavor is dark malt, malt and hop bitterness, oak, charcoal, licorice, alcohol, and a dry finish.  Full body, medium warmth and carbonation.

#2300! The Dan Journal #487. 220z Bomber. Pours pitch with a dark brown hue. Khaki finger width of head. Aromas of cola, fudge and dark dried fruits. Full bodied with a smooth body, moderate effervescence and a faint hop profile. Flavors of dark berries and a subtle coffee note. A good amount of chocolate flavors and sweet cola nuance. Mild spices and trace anise. The decent alcohol burn shines as the beer comes to temperature. Well worth the milestone! Delicious brew!
Draft at RnH with Linh, Thi and Vi. Pours a dark brown, practically black body with slight lacing. Aroma is deep roasted coffee. Mouthfeel is medium with notes of coffee, smoke, roast, thin fruits?

Bottle. Heavy malt aromas of toasted, molasses and dark chocolate, moderate resin and earth for the hops and yeast, with a background note of raisin. Head is small, frothy, light brown with no lacing and is mostly diminishing, Color is dark brown. Flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes lightly sweet and acidic and moderately to heavily bitter. Palate is on the fuller side of medium, almost syrupy, with a lively carbonation and a very dry finish. This is an awesome Baltic Porter, full of everything you want from the style, deep, rich and robust.

bottle-RBWG.  hmmm, i have been wanting to try this beer for many years.  however, i come to be a little dissapointed.  dark brown almost black with a small fizzy kacki head.  oxidized dark chocolate nose lightly fussel anise on the nose.  deep roasty flavors with alot of chocolate sweetness.  full body with a bit of carbonation.  not as good as i hoped and expected but probably better fresh.  alot of rasin and dark chocolate on the finish.  also detect greeen apples on the nose.  infected sample?  hmmmm must revisit!

2010 vintage. Aged over 1 year. 22oz Bomber into a snifter. Pours a
solid black with a thin mocha head that didnt last but had good lace
with what was there. Strong aroma, smoke, coffee, almonds, heavy roasted malt. Flavor is tons of chocolate, coffee, roastiness, and a very subtle underlying bitterness. Rich and creamy mouthfeel. Great porter.  I wish I had put more than 1 bottle in the cellar! Desire to drink more is
high. But look out for that ABV, it can hit you fast. You will NOT go
wrong with this one.

Pours black with a thin beige head and no lacing. strong, sweet aroma of molasses and some woodyness. Rich, syrupy mouthfeel with low carbonation. taste of chocolate, cream, whiskey, smoke, wood, dark malt and caramel. finishes warm and creamy. excellent beer!

Bottle pour into shaker glass. Dark pour with formidable even head. Light finger lacing. Aroma is chocolate and dark fruits. Light alcohol on the nose. Taste is lightly roasted chocolate malts, little dark fruit. Pleasant sweetness to the taste but not to a fault. Light alcohol finish. Slick slightly creamy consistency. Some light carbonation throughout. Average easy alcohol finish. Overall a very decent Baltic porter.

Bottle from DalzAle. Rich black brown pour with a quick thin tan head that fades to a tiny collar. Aroma is nice prune and rasins with some bitter chocolate. Taste is more bitter chocolate and prunes and roasted malt. Palate is medium to full mouthfeel with a subtle fizz and finishes dry. Very nice, will definitly be picking this up again.

Draft at The Shepherd and Knucklehead pub in New Jersey while on a business trip in February 2011.  Pours black with a little bit of brown around the edges and a very thin layer of beige foam.  Aroma of dark roasted malts, dark chocolate, and hints of smoke and leather.  Flavor has nice smooth chocolate, dark fudge, anise, grainy dark and light burnt malts, and hints of dark fruit.  Creamy good carbonation.  Nicely drinkable porter for a cold day in the northeast away from sunny San Diego.  (427, 490)

Pours pitch black with a three-finger, latte head.

Heavy chocolate and malt aromas.  Some coffee deep in there.  It smells like its going to drink like a milkshake.  Big, rich, stout malt aromas.

Rich, complex taste.  Sweet malts tempered by dark roast.  Chocolate, dark berries, pine, toffee, more chocolate.  Tastes too rich and complex to drink fast.  This is a sipper.  Its fairly sharply carbonated but it has a creamy body.

Excellent.  Im going to be sipping on this bomber and loving it.

2009 version from a 22oz bottle into a Rochefort glass.

The beer is a very dark black, hardly showing any brown held up to the light. The head is a very dark brown that rises about 2 fingers and provides nice retention and great retention. 

The aroma is really light with notes of coffee, raisins and alcohol. Id really like something a little more bold and definitive. 

The taste is phenominal. There are really nice sweet malts of sweet chocolate and cherry with a very smooth light bitter hoppy finish. Its so balanced and complete.

The mouthfeel is great, and its highly drinkable

Bottle. Darkest brown you can get without being black for the body, and a darker tan head.  Light roast, caramel, raisins, slight chocolate and very light coffee all in the aroma...with some sweetness.  Flavor is nicely rich with some raisiny sweetness featured behind lightly roasted malts, bit of smoke and savory finish.  Medium to thicker body, with softer carbonation.  Nice brew.

22 oz. bottle in a shaker.  Black pour with medium brown head.  Aroma of peanut shells and coffee.  A little spiciness from the hops right up front with a rich nutty flavor.  Smooth, mildly bitter finish.  Very enjoyable.  Would have probably been better on a colder night.
Bottle from Cavie.  Dark pour with a huge brown head.  Aroma is dark malts with tons of coffee and chocolate.  Taste is very bitter bakers cocoa, a little coffee, roasted, and great grains.

Bottle with big thanks to mcox90.  Pours an extremely black color with a tannish foamy head.  Aroma is a very dark, brown chocolate with a nice roasted coffee bean nose.  This smells very nice.  Flavor is roasted coffee and malts, with a nice sweet flavor of milk and cream.  Nice toasted finish.  This is awesome!

pours pitch black with a healthy sized tan head that shrinks and leaves a tiny little coating. coffee notes coming through the nose as well as some roastiness with a hint of booze. taste is toasty chocolate malts with a hint of booze and bitterness towards the finish.

Bottle, shared with Mike. Oh boy, this looks amazing: thick, hearty, opaque brown with a dark brown crown that seems to rise from the depths like slow-cooking soufflé. Aroma is intensely malty, with sweet brown bread, molasses, and lots of vinous dark fruit character. Warming finish, oily mouthfeel. Rich and complex, amazing.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Big bottle from trade w/Boliv.  A huge porter here.  Very thick.  frothy nut brown colored head/thick lacing through out that you can actually feel when you drink.  roasty, smokey, nutty, warming nice balance.  Nice sweet malty cocoa finish.  bravo--this $hit rocks

Big bottle.  Strong coffee & roasted aroma. Deep brown to black color, foamy tan head.   Medium to full body, seems to have above average carbonation, but softened by the body.  Long finish which is biter and burnt tones.  Complex taste that is bitter but also brings out more of the coffee, roasted and malts.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2012 Very good porter. This is one of my top ten favorite beers. Would not have guessed smuttynose made this. Introduces complexity and balance and many levels on nose and flavoes. Body is thick. Very highly recommended.

(2008 Vintage) Extreme dark brown, well just call it black with a thin skiff floating on to. Strong aroma, smoky salt, coffee, almonds, heavy roasted malt. This aroma is powerful. Roasted smoky flavor thats slightly cedary, thick dark fruit, and mild chalk. Silva just kicked Belfort so hard in the face Jeff shat himself. Nice chocolate presence, and not to bitter. I think the Baltic porter is becoming one of my favorite styles. THANKS GULLY

2008 Vintage. Thank you so much Dany! Black, small light brown head and ring. Roasty aroma, raisins, almond, dark fruit, more fruit, bit of coffee and almost an oak nose. Really good. The taste is better than the aroma. Big roast, chocolate and bitterness, dough, brown sugar, molasses, more chocolate, light alc heat without the alc flavour, Silva Vs Belfort. Huge thick flavour. Simply a stunning tasting event. Which I wasnt sharing this so I could hoard it for myself. Light spice, plenty of soft nutty flavors, stronger than soothing flavors. This beer build in greatness as I get further along. Great mouth feel, great beer.

Draft @ The White Horse, Parsons Green SW6. Pours a dark brown almost black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty chocolate and molasses aroma with some hints of dark fruit. Fruity roasted malty caramel and chocolate flavor with some hints of dark fruit. Has aroasted malty dark chocolate finish.

2009 Vintage.  Enjoyed from a 22oz bomber in a stemless wine glass.  the beer pours a nice black hue, with a low tan head.  The nose shows really appetizing characters of chocolate milk, dark chocolate, and a slight roast note; along with a background note of Munich and perhaps a medium lovibond crystal malt.  Any hop character has long fallen out of solution.  The palate shows much of what was advertised in the aroma, with a touch more emphasis on roasted character.  Milk chocolate, mellow roasted flavors, a nice residual caramel/toasted malt sweetness, and a finish that is absolutely surprising in its dryness.  Again, hop bitterness seems nonexistent, indicating that the alcohol may be adding a touch of bitterness, along with the roasted malt.  Overall, the beer shows a level of complexity and refinement that is exemplary.  A stellar example of the style.

This beer pours a very dark brown with nice looking creamy head.
A slight hint of aromatic hops, a mocha and sweet brown maltiness.
I enjoyed the dark roasted smoky backbone, and the malty profile.
Pours a dark brown with a small creamy head.  Aroma of chocolate, roast malt, molasses, raisins.  Flavor is nice roast, coffee, chocolate and fruit.  A pretty good brew.

Bomber, pours jet black w/ a dense slightly red-tinted head, aroma is complex with milk chocolate, some dried fruit,, and various other elements in smaller quantities, sharp roastiness throughout, finishes slighty dry with a lactic tang, tasty brew, great example of the style

Bottle. Poured into a Duvel tulip glass a dark brown color with some reddish mahagony highlights. Nice tan head that collars around the rim but fades rather quicker than I had expected. Nice aroma of dark chocolate, slight roast, and brown sugar. I really am hoping this thing tastes just as good as it smells! Medium/heavy mouthfeel. Very smooth drinking is the first thing that comes to mind for me. The dark chocolate notes are sweet with very little bitterness. Some dark fruit notes as well blended into the flavor. A hint of smokiness/roast as well in the finish. Overall, pretty pleased with this one.

27th March 2009 Opaque black beer. Chocolate coloured frothy head. Soft palate. Creamy dark malt, a hint of chocolate and a subtle note of dark fruit - cherry and plum. An aniseed cherry finish with an overriding creamy malt. Surely an imperial porter?

bomber.  Shared at the January Houston RB Tasting at my place.  Pours black with a brown head.  Nose is of coffee.  Taste is of coffee and chocolate.  Mouthfeel is medium and a bit chalky.  Tastes more like an imperial stout than a porter.  Nice

Review from notes, sampled 1/26/2008 2008 vintage
22oz Bomber into a Sam Adams glass.

Pours a solid black with a thin mocha head that doesnt stick around long, but does leave some nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is sweet almost a lactose sweet smell with some roasted grain, coffee and some faint raisin in there too. The taste hits you with a lot at once. First I got some hops then chocolate then coffee then some alcohol. Roasty bitterness in the end sits in your gullet just begging you to take another sip. Mouthfeel is thick and creamy. This is an excellent brew! I better buy up some more before they are all gone. Great cellar candidate too. Another excellent brew from Smuttynose.

Bottle shared by maltomeal at the January 2011 RB tasting. Black with a tan head. Huge chocolate and malty nose. Taste of solid burnt malts, chocolate, alcohol is well hidden like an imperial stout. Delicious.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: January Houston Tasting. Thanks to Maltomeal. Pours a dark black with cocoa head. Nose of mocha, cocoa with roast notes. Flavor is roasted malts and coffee. Rich, creamy and luscious.

Bottle from Josh - thank you!  Thinnish, quickly fading brown/tan head.  Aroma is coffee/supporting roasted malt, raisin/date, and sweet malt.  Taste is chalky, dry coffee followed by roasted malt with sweet malt and raisin through the finish.  Nice balance between the coffee/roasted malt character up front and the supporting sweet/malt raisin through the finish.  Bit sticky in the mouth but not to the beers detriment.  The whole is more than the parts for me on this one.  I really like this beer.

Pours thin, but that is deceiving.  Great porter taste with tones of chocolate and smoke.  The smoky notes are subdued, which makes me enjoy this one even more.  Baltic Porters are becoming one of my favorite styles of porters and this one is a super example.  Be careful, the ABV will sneak up on you.

Dark brown pour from bottle obtained in trade from Bricks.  Nice, malty aroma with hints of coffee and chocolate.  Taste is chocolate, burnt wood, caramel and light booze.  Well balanced, smooth and excellent.

22 oz Bottle  - pours a very dark brown/ near black with a nice tan head. Aromas of bitter chocolate, coffee, and dried fruit.  Perfectly balanced taste of the above mentioned aromas. Quite smooth and creamy. Light carbonation. Finishes with a barely noticeable slightly bitter kick and is very easy to drink - you dont get any strong and unnerving hints of alcohol anywhere despite the near 9% content.  My favorite porter to date!
Bottle. Pours black with brown head. Nose of roasted chocolate malts, earthy hops, caramel, fresh coffee and vanilla. Taste of creamy chocolate malts, licorice, coffee, raisin, vanilla and caramel.

Pours a dark brown, almost black with tall dark tan head. Smell is weaker than expected, but of roasted malts, dark fruits, raisins, and bread. Taste follows in smells footsteps; again weaker than I expected (especially at around 9% ABV); huge amount of raisins, alongside toffee malts and slight amounts of coffee, caramel, and brown sugar. A very slight tang almost like that of an oatmeal stout. Medium body, soft carbonation, and a creamy, sticky mouthfeel.

My second nice beer on new years.  pours a dark black and smells of delicious roasted coffee beans.  tastes of malt, chocolate, caramel, dark fruits, and lots of coffee.  Mouth feel is very creamy.  slight bitter finish so delicious.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2012 Deep black pour with a thick brown head. The pour wafts the intense aroma all the way up to your nose from the glass. Smells strongly of chocolate and coffee, with plenty of roasty character. Smells like a dream. Flavor is tons of chocolate, coffee, roastiness, and a very subtle underlying fruitiness. Rich and creamy mouthfeel. Stunningly delicious. All I can say is I want more.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2014 7 oz NYE tasting....thanks, Todd....this is a real porter...wonderful....bold coffee nose thru the tan head; beautiful black color (sure this isnât a stout?)...sweet coffee taste and lingering sweet finish...wow....will do this one again...and again...beautiful example of the porter brew...

UPDATED: APR 2, 2011 22 oz bottle. Conditioned in 2010. Pours almost black with nice dark colored head. Nice toasted notes on the nose, big flavors or coffee and rains, rich and creamy mouthfeel. Great beer, will commit a few to the cellar.

Pours dark brown with a dark tan/reddish head.  Aroma is mostly roasted malts and sweet dark chocolate.  Taste has dark roasted espresso notes with bittersweet chocolate and a hint of alcohol.  It finishes nicely with citrusy hops and lingering roasted malts. Mouthfeel is full bodied, creamy, silky, and sticky.  Moderate carbonation.  This is delicious!
Bottle at White Horse Parsons Green post GBBF.  Lots of intense choc on aroma.  Its got a touch of ash, roasted, big choc and some good harsh intense choc.  But not my favourite.  Bit harsh.

(22oz bottle courtesy of markwise. bottled in 2009).  Pours black with tan head.  Nice lacing and nice small carbonation bubble action.  Aroma of chocolate, dried dark fruits, and coffee.  Taste is semi-sweet with a pleasant roasty bitterness following.  Full bodied with creamy/slick texture and bitter finish.  This is a very nice beer.

22 ounce bottle, from November 2010.  Served in a pint glass, the beer pours dark brown/black with about an inch and a half tan head.  Head retention and lacing are both pretty good.  Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, caramel and dark fruit.  I think the brew tastes just like the aroma, but with the roasted malt, dark fruit and coffee flavors being the strongest.  Mouthfeel/body is full, its creamy and rich with moderate carbonation.  The drinkability is amazing, its very smooth and goes down quite easy.  The 9% ABV isnt noticable at all in the aroma or taste, which also helps make this beer easy to drink.  I think this is a fine Baltic Porter, and a great overall brew too.  Definitely recommended, and a great deal at $5.99 a bottle.

Damn malt monsters get me every time!  Poured near pitch black out of 22oz black.  Strong aroma of coffee.  Reminds me of their imperial stout that I also rated high.  All around, this is a serious ale that is perfect for the winter.

(22oz bottle thanks to mar) near black pour, thick lasting tan head and nice coating. Nose of moss, caramel, raisins, sweet chocolate malt, fudge, and a bit of maple. Taste of honey, caramel, toastiness, fudgey, awesome. Medium body, creamy, sweet toasty linger. Very nice.
2009 Bottle thanks to jmu500.  Black pour with a deep khaki head.  Thick chewy raisins, chocolate, roasted malts, and dark fruits.  Great chewy palate, thick malts, dark fruits,  and roasted coffee.

Bomber. Pours black with a creamy tan head. Aroma is very roasty, deep rich chocolate and espresso notes, a bit of coffee grounds and some dark chocolate candy sweetness, also a bit woody and earthy. Flavor starts with a very rich chocolate, both sweet and bitter chocolate with some burnt toast. Keeps some strong espresso notes with a bitter cocoa powder type of finish. Medium to full body and a softer carbonation. Excellent beer.

22oz bottle. Pours black with a thin short-lived brown head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, and fruit with a hint of smoke and a touch of alcohol. Flavor starts sweet with caramel and fruitcake and earthy coffee. Chocolate and overdone toast come in along with a subtle yet still noticeable resiny hop character. Warm alcohol and chocolate and lots of fruity esters in the finish along with a touch of alcohol bitterness. Mouthfeel is full-bodied, almost oily, and moderately carbonated. Overall, rich , complex, and quite tasty. Slightly unrefined, though, and more imperial stout than baltic porter, but still good.

A: Pours a very dark brown bordering on black with a nice light-brown head.

S: Pretty good amount of roasted malt alongside chocolate, a bit of coffee, and hints of dark fruits.

T: Chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, dark fruits, mild earthy hops.

M: Thick and creamy yet a bit dry. Very smooth.

D: A nice sipper. Probably my favorite Smuttynose beer to date.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-05-2010

Sampled at Freetail at the La Muerta bottle share.  A good way to start the day/morning before the release!!  Poured a clear, deep brown body with just a ring of off-white head.  Very leggy! Aromas of caramel, roasty, espresso and some alcohol.  Flavors of plums, sweet fresh coffee, roasty, medium coffee bitter finish thats very smooth.  Active, fine carbonation with a medium to full mouthfeel.  This was/is a great Baltic porter!!

Bottle/22oz/2009 Bottling - Pours a very dark, oily black in color with almost no head... but what there is is dark tan... and very little carbonation.  Aroma is of dark roasted malts, chocolate, espresso, a bit of alcohol and mild of pine resin hops.  Flavor is thick and chewy... like a good Impy... with chocolate, dark roasted malts and a medium bitterness,  I am having a hard time not thinking of this as an Imperial Stout.  Really smooth, love the chocolate and easy drinking.  Some lingering bitterness and alcohol burn at the end... simply awesome!

Tasted from a 22 oz. bottle purchased in Keene, New Hampshire.  Pours a very deep black appearance with a thick black-cream head.  Deep malty aroma like an Imperial Stout.  Creamy, very dark porter.  Alcohol is masked quite well.

Got as an extra in a trade. Bottle from the 2009 vintage. This has to be one of the blackest, thickest porters Ive seen in a long time. From the first pour, the  color is jet black and pretty thick, syrup like thick. The aromas were full of chocolate with roasted hop character to it. The head was somewhat thin and sparse, but a pretty brown color. The head retention wasnt too impressive, and the carbonation wasnt too strong,  but for a porter I wont complain. Many of the flavors held roasted qualities and it was a great beer to share with friends.

Bottle of 2009 vintage.  Nice rich dark pour with great presence.  Roast and light hop notes reveal the taste to be a little lacking which I speculate may be due to the length of storage.  Not bad but flavor seemed to drop off towards the finish.

2009 bottle, website says bottled in early November so this is almost a year old and I just bought it off the shelf for a great price ;).  Pours a nice shinny dark near black cola with a fizzy foamy light tan froth.  Good amount of hop oxidation in the aroma, pine needles and the likes which make me want their imperial stout that I loved, nice round dark roast, thick and very dark, bit of the fruit that I love to find, just too much hop oxidation in the way, not sure if it would be better fresher or after another year or two.  Flavor follows, dry roast upfront, oxidized pinny hops, bit of fruit and rich oily dark chocolate in the finish leading to a alcohol burn that ruins the experience a bit.  Medium/full bodied, creamy and chalky with spritzy carbonation, actually dry for the style, as it warms carbonation becomes more fluffy, so odd because it is dry and yet creamy and fluffy at the same time .  So far didnt quite do it for me like the impy stout did, this doesnt have the refinement a lagered big porter should have.  Definitely better as it as warmed, little bit more of the lagered character, round fruitiness, but still the harsh roast and aggressive hops combined with the showing alcohol just diminish what really could be a world class baltic porter, pretty delicious but just a bit out of sorts, duck rabbit, flossmoor and others nudge this one out.

Bottle. Pours black color with a large frothy brown head that was lasting with excellent lacing. Heavy toasted dark chocolate, coffee and dark fruit aroma. Medium to full body with a thick smooth texture and flat carbonation. Heavy toasted sweet malt bittersweet flavor with a medium  to heavy bittersweet finish of long duration. This is a standout porter.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 1pint 6oz bottle into an imperial pint glass. It is labeled as "Bottle Conditioned In 2009" and there is no ABV%. 

Appearance: It has a slow thick pour which is very dark. In the glass it looks nearly opaque and black in color. On top there is a tall light brown head. The head has good retention and leaves some splotchy lacing on the glass. 

Smell: The aroma has sweet and roasty maltiness. Its bready and grainy with hints of dark fruit and noticeable alcohol. 

Taste/Palate: There is a lot of full bodied sweet dark roasted barley malt wrapped up with some mellow boozy alcohol. There are notes of chocolate, dark dried fruits, golden raisons, burnt sugar and dark/burnt toasted bread. The finish has some leafy hop flavor and mild bitterness creeping in for some balance. Overall it still has plenty of residual sweetness in the end. Its not overpowering or cloying at all but it will slow down the drinkability as it lets you know its a big beer. On the tongue it has a slick viscose feel. There is just enough carbonation to ease it over the palate. 

Notes: I have to say that I love this beer. I love big complex dark beers and this one delivers!!!

Keg Handpump at the White Horse, Parsons Green 06/08/2010
Big coffee roast aroma. Black rich on the palate and strong in alcohol with a hint of dryness in a lasting coffee roast finish.
Black with a milkshake cream head.  Thick and milky on the nose.  Smoked and roasty with a spiky carbonation.  Very rich.  Some dark chocolate bitterness tops it all off.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2011 Bottle (GBBF2010) (6:4:6:3:12=3.1)
6 Sweet roasty malts. A touch yeasty too.
4 Almost black, tiny head.
6 Simple sticky heavily roasted malts in the taste. Burntness combined with the hopping comes over as liquorice.
3 Slick palate, not quite slimy. Finish massively marmitey.
12 Spoilt by the marmite, but not a bad beer.
Rerate: 660ml bottle (ChrisOs pre-GBBF2011 "Donkey Dork Lord" shindig) (6:5:5:2:9=2.7)
Looks beautiful crowned with a lovely dark head, but the aroma has some acidic tones that detract from the roast. Oooh, there in the taste too, not good. Quality issues?

Black colour, small brown head. Aroma is very much liquorice, alcohol, some earth, caramel and mild herbal notes. Flavour is quite much the same along with some mild toasted notes.

Bottle courtesy of ketchepillar. Pours a deep black with a good fluffy head and good lace. The aroma is dominated by fig and dark fruit with some floral notes in there as well. The flavor is bitter chocolate matched perfectly with coffee roastiness and a bit of burnt toast. The palate is big and creamy.

From tap at White Horse. Pours dark brown to black with a small tan head. Aroma dark roasted malty and breadish. Dark hard roasted malt flavoured. Mild liqourice and dark chocolate. Mild hardroasted acidic touch into the finish.

The pour reveals a deep black color with a thin, light brown head. Solid aroma of chocolate, roasted malt and fruits. Very good flavor of chocolate, roasted malt and fruits, its also dry and bitter in the end. The body is light to medium with a creamy texture and gentle carbonation. This is very good, another smash hit by Smuttynose.
Bomber from NBD in NYC. 2009. This beer is great. Nice cherry in aroma. Excellent chocolate. Some alcohol, but in a good way. Not much. Nice dark chocolate in the finish.
Black with a creamy light brown head.  Good strong chocolate aroma and taste with citrus notes, a mild bitterness, and a creamy palate.
The aroma and flavor of smoke and raisins is so prevalent the color is dark with a nice tan head on top.

Bottle at home ... deep black ... bubbly tan head ... thin roast toffee roast malts nose ... soft roast ... deep toffee ... nice rounded toffee malts ... light chocolate ... little raisins ... actually quite rounded.

Pours a dark black with a dark brown head. Looks awesome. Aroma is cocoa mixed with raisins, wood, pretty great, not as overpowering as i would have liked. The taste was a mix of dark fruit, cocoa, raisin, plum, maybe some wood. very complex that doesnt quit. excellent wood aftertaste. heavy mouthfeel, medium alcohol warming ability with a smooth finish. This is a really great beer.
Dark chocolate, red apple, fresh rubber. dark dark brown, dark tan head. rich chocolate nose, creamy sweet middle, toasty dry finish.

Thanks to Ucusty and my secret santa (I think) for the bottles of this!  Pours black with a somewhat small tan head.  Aroma of dark chocolate, earth, leaves, pumpernickel, and vanilla.  A little subdued.  Tastes of dark chocolate, espresso, fudge, caramel, wood and leaves.  Finishes very rounded and nearly "clean" with bitter coffee, dark chocolate, cocoa, and a toasty/leafy hop flavor.  Amazing transition between initial flavors and finish!  Nearly full bodied with appropriate carbonation and texture.  So so good!!

pours black with a thin beige head and no lacing.  strong, sweet aroma of molasses and some woodyness.  Rich, syrupy mouthfeel with low carbonation.  taste of chocolate, cream, whisky, smoke, wood, dark malt and caramel.  finishes warm with a nice alcohol burn.  excellent beer!

not entirely fond of the style this brew could change that. fig newton and nutty with a full frothy body and carbonation. full mouthfeel thick and satisfying. toasted coffee and alcohol, would have liked to feel and taste a bit more rye and caraway as it is my traditional favorite characteristic, yet no doubt this brew is a winner thru and thru.

Serving: Bottle. 
It pours almost black with a foamy tan head.  The nose is roasty but not burnt with notes of raisin and dark fruit.  It is a little viscous on the palate and has notes of boozy, dark fruit, roasted malt, and a bit of earthiness.  The alcohol strikes me as being a bit obvious.  Medium to rich in body with soft carbonation and a lingering roasty finish.  Overall a very solid example of the style and a very tasty brew.

A-pours a deep black color with a decent amount of dark khaki head

S-strong roasted malt smell with notes of coffee and a little citrus

T-taste like it smells, strong roasted malt, some nice bitter chocolate, some taste of citrus and a hint of bitter hops

M-pretty smooth, slightly creamy and chewy and not too much carbonation, light warming and taste of alcohol

D-quite drinkable with the smoothness taken back slightly by the hops/carbonation combo

Black pour with medium sized brown head. Aroma full of raison and fig. A mesh of lactose sugar and cocoa, creamy and heavenly. A perfect mouthfeel gives rise to a silky milk chocolate, coffee, nuts, light cream and molasses. Fig newton dunked in chocolate milk with a side of peanuts. Delicate.

Bomber from Pristine Liquors in Spring Hill, FL. Pours a beautiful black with mean brown head. Aroma is sweet coffee, chocolate, and toffee. Flavor is dominated by coffee with some mollasses and burnt chocolate...Fucking delicious. Thick mouthfeel thats as smooth as can be with a great warmth to it...One of my new favorites...love the Smuttynose Big Beer series.

Pours a black color with a caramel colored head.   Has an aroma of dark fruit, with hints of chocolate and coffee.  The alcohol also comes through on the nose.  Has a sweet taste up front with a velvety chocolate taste in the middle.  A nice subtle bitterness on the finish.  Leave some chocolate notes on the tongue with the aftertaste.  Delicious brew.

Hell yeah.  Tons of roasted sweet roasted malts, coffee, and fruit in the aroma and flavor.  It approaches the point of being too sweet but doesnt go overboard. Well balanced. This beer instantly gave me a strong desire to go do the backstroke in the Gulf of Bothnia.

Wow. WOW. 750 ml bottle pours midnight black and oily into a snifter, fluffy, lively brown head. Light lacing. Nose is heavy with Sumatran coffee, exotic chocolate, raisins, burnt toffee, plum. Taste is dominated by coffee and chocoate, with some dark fruit coming through on the palate. Extremely clean finish for the style, no lasting bitterness, just a mild, pleasant coating on the inside of the mouth. One of my new favorites. Hallelujah.

Pours black with a tan head. The aroma has chocolate, licorice, smoke, berries, and roasted malt. The flavor reminds me of salty Dutch licorice. Raspberries, dark chocolate, smoke, black pepper, flint and a tun of licorice. on the palate. Kick ass porter!
A jet black beer with nice tan/brown head. Scent is sweet malts. Taste is coffee and some fruit. NICE

22oz in a shaker glass.  Pours dark, dark brown (near black) with a dark tan, lacy head.  Normally I dont like porters, but this one is incredible.  Strong aroma of chocolate and roasted malts.  The beer is sweet, but not too sweet.  The initial flavor is that of raisins and chocolate, with a lingering chocolate finish.  Full bodied, and sort of has an oily texture.  A great porter.

Black pur with a nice looking brown head.  Aroma is malty with chocolate and raisin.  Flavor is as intense as any other beer Ive had. Huge upfront blast of coffee and chocolate.  After the initial surprise, there was a long and lingering dark fruit and oakey, earthy flavor.   Absolutely incredible.  This beer is probably one of the best I have ever had.

Bottle from Sudsys.  Pours black with tan, 1 finger, fizzy head, dissipating rather quickly to a capping film.  A big nose of chocolate and roast, mild caramel and some coffee undertones.  Flavor is chocolate with some prominent fruit, raisin and plum, dark cherries.  Lots of roast with some astringent bitterness and some coffee.  Thick and oily, clinging to the palate.  Complex and balanced, scary drinkable, and a definite repeater.

This lovely 22oz bomber is what i needed on this cold rainy night. Poured into my snifter this pure back beer had bubbled clinging to the glass and a 1.5 finger tan head that faded. The aroma is what malt lovers touch themselves dreaming of. Roasted with coffee chocolate and some figs. Also getting some smoke and some alcohol note with a touch of spice. The taste was just a mellow sweetness with some more dried fruit and coffee bitter. But for such a complex beer it goes does easy with a light body. You can drink the whole bottle no problem.

Bottle, thanks to Glouglouburp. Pours viscous black, with a thin tan head, mildly persistent, spotty lacing. Nose is fantastic! Soy, smoke, chocolate, graphite, nice fruit. Flavors are intense but very balanced, quite bitter, with the notes trending towards sarsparilla, mocha, mineral, spice, pepper, smoke, mild dark fruits. A lovely beer.

Aroma is that rich German Chocolate cake and burnt brown sugar that I have enjoyed in  superiour Old ales. Doesnt hold up for long . Flavor is Dark malt,chocolate brownie,with that little hint of christmas anise in finish,just a hint of the alcohol. The malting and flavors is nearly perfect,a little more body and this would be near the top

pours jet black with a tan head. Nose is dark fruit, candy sugar, licorice and chocolate. Flavor is roast and chocolate, plums, figs and coffee. Finish is long, bitter and chocolate. Very good! So smooth

22 oz bottle. Dark mahogany with a thick tan head that quickly fades to a small ring. Aroma of dark roasted barley, coffee, chocolate and vanilla. The flavor is sweet chocolate malt and coffee mostly, the bitter roasted malt is there but not as much as the aroma would indicate. Full body with average carbonation and a thick creamy mouth feel. This one has the aroma of an Imp Stout but the lighter body and flavor like a Baltic Porter. Very rich and good.

Really nice beer.  This is my first baltic porter, and you can tell that it is lager fermented.  Thats the real distinguishing factor from an RIS.  Taste is roast, chocolate, a little hops but not heavy.  Aroma of coffee, molasses and dark fruit.  Its relatively light on the mouth feel, very clean and smooth. Color is pitch black.  Delish.
From a bottle poured dark brown with a very small head.  Sweet toasted malty flavor with a lingering finish.

Bottle thanks to pabs311. Pours black with a medium dark brown heady that is thick but dissipates quite quickly. Aroma is full of roasted malts and coffe with hints of dark fruits and raisin. Flavor begins bitter with a roasted coffee note, but notes of dark fruits grown in to the finish.
solid beer, with a mulitude of flavors with cocoa, coffe. everlasting bitterness. solid

The aroma is very sweet and roasted with a bit of hops. The appearance is dark brown with a tan head that just keeps lasting. The taste is like the aroma with a fairly dry finish. The palate is thick, Overall this is good but not great.

My favorite baltic porter- smutty nose nailed this beer. Delightful jet black color, thick, heavy body. nose has lots of dried fruit and a slight tart quality behind the big toasted malt. The taste has big chocolate, raisin, and toasted malt.

Aroma is of roast and dark fruits.  Pours an opaque black, with a big tan head.  Slick and smooth mouthfeel, with flavor notes of coffee, roast, cocoa, and a touch of molasses.  An exceptional beer to drink on a chilly night.
(draught) black with tan head. Nice toasted malt aromas. Flavor of roast malts, coffee, dark chocolate, dark fruits. Another excellent Smuttynose beer.

Bottle - Deep and dark with a foamy tan head. Raisins and dark fruit, chocolaty malt with a touch of booze. Sweet malt, coffee grounds, a bit of nuttiness, with some espresso on the finish. Smooth and full-bodied--velvety and wonderful.
Bottle. Pours motoroil black with a tan head. Flavor is coffee, chocolate, raisins. Not bad for $4.

Black pour with a small brown head.  Cocoa and coffe aroma with just a slight hint of dark fruit brown sugar.  Milk chocolate flavor with some cold pressed coffee, a hint of plum,  little burnt sbrown sugar, and some lingering hop bitterness.  Creamy medium full body wit lots of carbonation.

Bottle 22 oz, thanks Blankboy. Powerful aroma. There is a lot of chocolate, some coffee, vanilla, anise and molasses. Flavor is chocolate, sweet malts and grape tannins. Palate is different than most baltic porters or imperial stouts. It is light in a positive way, it makes it more refreshing. Very enjoyable for its heavy taste.

Wonderful malty aroma with coffee, some chocolate, caramel and some toast.  Body is dark with a light toffee head.  Toasted slightly bitter flavor with some bready coffee notes.  Mouth feel is lightly carbonated with a nicely balanced body.  Overall, delicious Smuttynose offering.

A: The pour is dark brown, bordering on black with a fluffy brown head.

S: The aroma is good, if not a bit simple. A lot of chocolate and roasted malt with a bit of vanilla.

T: A wonderful chocolate flavor is the star of the show. Roasted malt and coffee provide a nice background and contrast of flavors.

M: Medium bodied with carbonation that is actually a bit on the lighter side.

D: Ive had a few different Baltic porters and this one is easily the best. Great flavors and a nice body (rather than being thin and "lagery").

Generally, if Im going to drink a hefty dark beer, Ill stick with stout. I like porter, too, but Im just a stout guy. I think it has something to do with Tom Waits. This is a great porter if youre in the mood, though. Malty, with a predominate flavor of dark roasted coffee.  Just a bit of smokiness and burnt flavors.  Ive had almost everything from the Smuttynose Big Beer series at this point, and there is not one beer from it I would hesitate to recommend.

From bomber. Chocolate, licorice, coffee, molasses. Rich and sweet nose with mild carbonic-metal tang, with light bitter hops. Dark brown-black clear with thick foamy tan lacing head. Medium body with medium carbonation, slightly oily, with a bit of warming and light carbonic burn. Starts with medium sweetness of molasses, chocolate, and raisins. Mild bitter coffee, a touch of smoke or burnt malt. Carbonic tang, with mild dry nutty bitter finish. Rich and fairly complex, this is a nice Baltic porter. After is smooth with mild chocolate sweetness and pleasant bitter dryness.

Whoa, serious beer. Served with a nice sized, light tan, fine foamy head and good lace. Aroma is malty, sweet, dark ripe fruit, a bit roasty and good. Ditto flavor and all of that comes out much more boldly. Body is great and carbonation too. Finish is mainly sweet with some bitterness to temper. A bit too big to be a session, but nevertheless a major, world class brew.

Bottled. thx. to Papsoe for this. Pitch black coloured. Dense black head. Aroma of roast, light plums, liqourice, spice, chocolate and some herbs. Flavour of chocolate, roast, alcohol, vague smoke, some burnt brown sugar, flowers and herbs. Some cocoa notable. Quite complex and surprinsingly smooth. Medium to full bodied. Ens on a roasty chocolaty bitterness. Really a treat in my book.

Very nice dark pour with beautiful dark brown head.  Solid nose reveals lots of chocolate and some light coffee/caramel notes with a hint of dark fruits.  The taste follows the nose very nicely and has a bit of alcohol burn and bitterness in the back end.  The sweetness is very nice but not cloying.  The dark fruity flavors are there to keep the beer from being a higher ABV version of Shakespeare Stout.  The mouthfeel isnt incredible for the style and could be more creamy but certainly isnt too thin.  A nice, nice beer.

The aroma is cocoa drust and sweet malt. Very nutty and dry. Dark chocolate balance and hints of dark berry. Dusty and nutty. Great.

The appearance is 8-ball black, with slushy brown head. Opaque, cherry red at the edges.

The flavor is very dark and bitter first. Burnt cookies. A more chocolatey finish, very rich. Sweetish, but with that nuttyness. Rich and full of flavor. Mild, pleasant alcohol burn.

The palate is smooth and oily at first, a bit of a drier, milky finish. A rich, darkly sweet beer. really excellent and yet very drinkable.

This poured a dark opaque with a thin lacing of head. Aroma has a strong mixture of raisins and dates. Taste is pretty sweet with raisins coming through stronger, and with a bit of cookie-dough like malts on the aftertaste. Coffee doesnt really stand out much on this one. Body is aIso quite light, moreso than most english porters. honestly I saw this as more of a strong dopplebock, but it is nonetheless a very enjoyable brew.
This did its job and then some! Poured black with a creamy tan head. Lasted forever in a good way. Aroma of chocolate and coffee. Same as it smelled. Not alcohol presence what so ever. Nicely done.

About a 1 inch plus brown head of fine and dense bubbles.  Light carbonation.  Nice aroma with lots of milk chocolate, roasted grains, a hint of coffee and some smoked malts.  Color is a very dark brown.  Velvety smooth mouthfeel with lots of sweet malts, more milk chocolate, a bit of mild coffee, burnt toast and some carbon.  Late dryness and slight bitterness.  Finishes strong and roasty.  Hides it alcohol very well.  Very flavorful and a bit drier than expected.  A good baltic porter.

really nice sweet baltic porter. color is chocolate and beige head.  nose is boozy and sweet. flavor is similar nice  mouth feel lotsa malt, vanilla and chocolate sweetness, some smooth cocoa. great boozy beer
08 vintage courtesy of some great trader on here, cant remember which one! great porter, has a tiny hint of heat in the finish to warm you. tons of chocolatew throught this hearty and tasty brew!

Pours solid black with a thick creamy brown head. Aroma of chocolate, vanilla, roasted malt and nut. Taste is sweet and  creamy initially then fading to a more bitter cocoa finish. Good balance, medium bodied.

22 oz bomber bottle from Supreme Liquors, Cambridge MA. Pitch black. Thin tan head. Big, fat and slightly oily in consistency. Lots of deep roasty malt together with bitter chocolate. coffee mocha throughout. Theres a touch of residual sweetness. Big, brash and, whilst maybe not majoring on complexity or refinement, it is certainly mighty tasty. A winner for me.

Bottle...  Poured near black, with a thick, frothy, light brown head.  Aroma of roasted grains, coffee, and alcohol booziness.
