Pours pitch black with mahogany edges when held up to light.  The mocha head is one inch thick and dense, lingers a while and leaves sporadic lacing throughout.  Big smell of roasted coffee and malts up front.  Dark chocolate aroma as well with some dark fruits, but its the sweet malts that steal the show.  Roasted coffee and sweet malts also dominate the taste with a sweet molasses and dark fruit flavor as well.  I also got some very subtle smoky tones as well.  Very well balanced.  This is one smooth beer with little carbonation and a nice palate coating mouthfeel.  This is one of the better baltic porters I have tasted and I would seek this one out.  Highly recommended!
Pours a deep brown color with a brown head.  Aroma is malty, nutty, bitter roast, and coffee.  Flavor is coffee, roast, some ash, and a nice chocolate bitter roast finish.

Beer pours dark as night with deep tan head, fingers thick.  Nice lacing on my beer mug.  Aroma was of bitter roast and milk.  The flavor was a full rich and sweet milky chocolate with lactic notes, some coffee flavor and lots of bitter roast to balance things out.  The mouthfeel on this guy was thick, almost chalky as it coated my tongue and mouth.  I really enjoyed this experience!

22oz bottle @Vero Beach Throwdown-pours a brown head and black color.  Aroma is dark malt-chocolate/molasses, some earthy hops.  Taste is dark malt-chocolate/molasses/licorice-acidic, earthy hops.  OK carbonation.  Not my style but interesting and nicely done.  Occasional.  Thanks MGumby for sharing.

Appearance: Pours a black body with a medium-sized, foamy, dark tan head.

Smell: Roasty aroma with full notes of blackstrap molasses and fire-charred aniseed. Lighter background hints of raisins and smoke.

Taste: Roasted, black malts thats all at once smokey and sweet. Tastes of bittersweet chocolate, licorice, molasses, and cauterized cream crowd the palate and swarm the taste buds. Earthy, spicy bitterness remains light. Touch of fruitiness. More smoke and roast on the sweetish finish.

Mouthfeel: A hair above medium-bodied. Medium carbonation.

Drinkability: A very drinkable, very enjoyable brew from Smuttynose.
22oz bottle.  Aroma of deep roast.  Sweet malt and molasses.  Pours deep Dark brown / black.  Smooth, creamy texture.  Very tasty.

Bottle via trade with The_Epeeist, thanks Chris.   Pours a nearly black color with a tan colored head.   Aroma os choclate, coffee, caramel.   Flavor is chocolate, coffee, dried dark fruits.   Palate si medium to full bodied, medium carbonation, finished bitter.   Really nice, on par with Perkunos!

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2009 2008 bomber from pforei. thanks paul! 
a viscous pour leads to an opaque nearly black shade of brown. its topped by a foam like marshmallow-y cocoa colored head that paints the glass as it retreats. aroma is faintly of coffee with a bunch of chocolate, black raisins and some ashy char. the palate is not even in the realm of sweet as far as baltics go... huge bonus. the flavor is rather port/ juicy red wine like with more black raisins and chocolate along with wood, roasty grain and a dry bittered finish. coffee pops up in the aftertaste. this leans on full bodied. very creamy texture and chewy mouth feel. simplistic and well crafted...

This was a bomber bottle at room temperature, which is definitely the way to sample dark beers.  Big brown head on this ol bear.  Another eccentric label drawing by Smuttynose.  Strong alcohol in the nose, with some sharp hops and yeast also - maybe even a touch of mold?  The flavor packs a wallop, and comes in somewhere between an imperial stout and an imperial porter.  It is definitely the most potent thing I have tasted out of Portsmouth - coffee, roast grains, a touch of figs and dates, and a little whiskey too.  There is a strong finish, with sweetness followed by cooling hops.  This brew will grab you by the collar and make you holler - and youll enjoy it too!
Pours black with a medium to large mocha head.  Aroma is dark roasts, espresso, vanilla, milk.  Taste is about the same.  A very good and creamy porter with a great mouthfeel!

Thanks to my brother for this!!!  Pours a deep rich brown color with light brown head.  Aroma is very fruity with dark fruit like plum and raisin as well as light anise notes becoming apparent.  Taste is light chocolate, dark fruit, and caramel malt.  Alcohol is well hidden and the beer finishes smooth and creamy.  Good stuff.

Bottle. Thick black with a dense head on the pour. Big sweetness, raisins, brick roast, that sort of stuff in the aroma in the aroma. Huge body, tons of sweet, lots of coal. Like a bad child on christmas. Quite a tasty brew.

(22oz bottle, vintage 2008) Large brown head atop solid black body.  Aroma is medium sweet, espresso, chocolate, cream.  Taste is moderately sweet, rich, chococoffee, some plum, caramel, faint smoke.  Some alcohol warming.  Smooth, full body with a lovely creaminess and some syrupiness.  What a great beer!

Bottle courtesy Degarth. Pours black with a one finger tan head that fades leaving some lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, and dark fruit. Taste is the same as aroma with a hint of caramel. Medium full mouthfeel with a mild to moderate amount of bitterness with warm but never hot alcohol. Very good.
22oz bottle. Pours pitch black in color with full brown head. Aroma sweet, dark chocolate and coffee. Taste dark chocolate and roasted coffee with dark chocolate bitter finish.

22oz.  Looks great - dark brown, opaque, pour with a dense tan head. Robust coffee and cocoa aroma, smells like its going to be tannic.  Bitter almonds and dark rummy type fruit.  Prevalent hop component also with alcohol.  Big flavor - immediately a bit too sweet for me, but very nice.  Lingering bitter finish.  Licorice jelly bean like flavor.  Chocolate in there too.  Massively fruity - plums, dates.  Big bodied.  Nicely brewed.

Bomber in trade with doublejay-pm94.  Yeah, this is what all big dark beers aspire to be.  This is a luciously smooth, big silky brew. Nose is of ripe fruit and ground up walnuts.  The moderate pour generates a heatly rolicking head that tastes great wven when you are slurping it up so it doesnt stain the precious counter top.  Head settles fast as do oily legs.  Body is big and full...like godzilla after pillaging Tokyo.  A big hit of chocolate malts is accented with coffee in the slightest amount.  this is huge since I have been raving on the over use of coffee as an ingredient as of late.  It actually works in this beer.  A gentle bozziness  complimented by a final hint of sweet rasins mixd with sun dried tomatoes eminates from the center of the mouthfeel that leads you stumbling for more in the finish of tingly coffee as the end.  A fine, fine brew.

Bottle: Near opaque pour with only a hint of light coming through at the edges. It also has a nice deep brown head. Charred aroma, along with an odd "sour milk" character- burnt dark fruits, lightly smoky/tobacco, a bit odd in the nose. The mouthfeel is creamy and mildly carbonated. Nice and dense. Lots of burnt character- dark fruits upfront, leading to more earthy character. Nice smooth booziness is present- dark chocolate liqueur balanced by some dark piny notes. Peppery and boozy overall with a balancing piny, espresso roast in the finish. A solid Baltic Porter.

22 ounce bottle from jjpm74.  Pour dark chocolate syrup brown with a lighter brown head.  The nose is of a mocha with too much chocolate.  It may be a flaw in coffee, but not so much here.  Robust flavors.  Coffee, fudge, raisins, chewing tobacco, and some ashy smoke.  Really good.  Huge body.  The carbonation is a bit prickly.  Dry roasted finish.  This is really a wonderful beer.

Easily in my top five favorite beers. Perhaps the best of Big Beer series. Smutty has created a fruity, chocolate and coffee dessert of a beer. Rich and complex, this one needs to be enjoyed like wine. Share the bottle! Found at Jaspers in Nashua.

Bottle shared with Midetd.  Pours  a pitch black with a nice tan head.  Has a medium mouthfeel with a black body.  Smells like a full body brew with heavy hops.  Tastes like I am getting a hop blast with some leather and earth.  Overall a nice brew.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2008 2008 22oz bottle. Pours pitch black with a creamy brown head. Aroma of coffee, roasted malt, and a bit of fruit. Big flavor, roasted coffee with dark fruits and a lingering roasted aftertaste. Great beer.

Bottle. Pours dark brown/black, with a brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, dark fruit, chocolate, molasses, and a bit of smoke. Flavor is roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, dark fruit, and smoke. Creamy body. Ends slightly bitter. Wow, this is nice.

Pours a very dark brown with a medium height, foamy, light brown head. Aroma is very chocolaty, with notes of raisins, coffee, and molasses. Initial taste is a pretty complex fruit filled sweetness. The body is very creamy and the finish is a long drawn out coffee malt flavor.

Pours dark dark brown with a tan head.  Aroma of toffee, chocolate, caramel, and roast.  Taste of chocolate, toffee, and dark fruit.  Has a bitter, but not overwhelming coffee finish.  Velvety mouthfeel and mrdium carbonation.  Excellent beer.

Bottle.  Dark brown pour, some tan head.  Aroma is some sweet malt, meat, smoke, chocolate, and roasted malt.  The flavor is similar, sweet chocolate malt, and some light smoke / meaty flavor in the back and finish.  The carbonation was a bit too high though.

Pours dark brown with a generous light brown head.  Smells of roasted malt, dark fruit, molasses, some roasted malt.  Tastes sweet and chocolatey with some spice elements.  More of an amped up porter than a typical Baltic porter, but nice.

22 oz bottle: Beautiful pour ... cascading tan head, settling into a soapy foam over dark black.  The aroma is thick and big, smoky and chocolatey.  Drinks with a thick oily complexion, the slight warming aspect the first impression.  The flavor leans towards burnt chocolate, bad coffee, and a bit of ashy smokiness.  Good.  (#3433, 4/23/2008)

Bottle. Aroma of coffee and roasted malt, pleasant, but rather straightforward for such an ambitious brew. Flavor continued to be fairly standard, coffee notes, chocolate notes, nuttiness. Mouthfeel was very, very thick, full, and ultimately creamy. Im a little torn on this beer, it started off for me with some clashes between the malty flavor, yeasty notes, and overall body. That said, it did grow on me to the point that disregarding my initial impressions I would rate it higher. Rambling, rambling, rambling, Ill leave it all as is for now and hope to give it another go.

Bottle.  Pours a dark black with a beautiful dark tan head that persists until the very end of the glass.  Aroma of coffee and roast.  Flavor of coffee, roast, chocolate, slight raisin as the beer warms.  This is a thick, rich beer, very reminiscent of an imperial stout.  Very creamy.  Excellent.

On tap at Sputyen Duyvil.  Deep dark black in color with a medium off white fluffy head. Chocolatety malty roasty aroma. Caramel toffee, nutty notes. Chocolatey hoppy malty flavor. Full bodied. Creamy and smooth palate. Nice beer. Very drinkable.

Aroma: lovely... coffee, roasted, wintery hops, chocolate fudge, earth, old wine, vinous, creamy. 
Flavour: mm... dry, roasted bitterness... seems more like sourish imperial stout, nutty, full-bodied, alcoholic bitterness. 
Appearance: oily black with tan head. 
Palate: very decent smoothness. Crisp. Feels fat.

Vanilla, chocolate, roasty, and almost smokey aroma.  Pours black with a thin tan head.  Thick on the palate, hoppy, roasted malts with chocolate and vanilla flavors, with hints of smoke in the finish.

Bottle.  Pours a dark opaque brown with a 1/2 inch chocolatey head.  Thick burnt malt, roasted, and coffee aroma.  Taste was thick full flavor of coffee, roastedness and a creaminess aspect.  Palate was thick and full.

Bottle. Pours black and oliy with light milk chocolate head. I knew this beer was gonna be good because I took one sip and my wife said I smelld of alcohol. Aroma of dark fruit, chocolate and burntness. Flavor the same with sweet chalky finish. Not a bad brew here, I liked it alot. Only thing is as I go to the end of the glass the taste was straight rubbing alcohol.

Small light brown head, good retention and a nice scattered lacing. Black in color, opaque. Darkly fruity nose, hint of raisin, chocolate, cocoa with a light roastiness. Body is med/full, silky on the palate. Choco roast flavors up front, medium sweet malts, light black patent notes, notes of vanilla bean, coffee and some berry notes as well. An almost dry, roasty finish. May not be a Baltic Porter exactly to style but it,s damn tastey stuff for sure. Bottle procured @statelineliquors.

As you would suspect, this beer poured black as night with a barely there brown head.  I didnt get much out of the aroma other than sweet malts.  The taste was equally dissappointing, 2-D.  It tasted like chocolate and alcohol.  On the same wavelength, the mouthfeel left a lot wanting.  It was chalky and so thin, it gave what ought to be a big, black full-bodied beer an almost transparent taste.  I would serve this beer with freshbaked chocolate chip cookies.

Bouteille 650ml, courtoisie de Hogtownharry. De couleur noire et opaque. Nez de malt rôti, de chocolat noir, de café, léger de crème et de houblon herbeux avec des notes dalcool et fruitées (raisins). Moyennement ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture riche et crémeuse. Goût de chocolat au lait accompagné dun léger goût de crème (petites notes lactiques) ainsi que de notes fruitées (raisins) et des traces de fumée (tabac et cendre) et de réglisse noire lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute rapidement un goût moyennement amer de malt assez rôti (légèrement brûlé) accompagné dun goût de chocolat noir puis progressivement un goût de café noir vient se rajouter pour dominer en finale avec un léger goût de houblon herbeux, asséchant et aux petites notes terreuses ainsi que des trace de noix grillées. Tout au long de la gorgée, on retrouve également un moyen goût dalcool légèrement réchauffant. Post-goût long et un peu sec, moyen-amer de rôti/ brûlé, de café, moyen de chocolat noir et dalcool avec des notes fruitées (moût de raisins) et fumées.

22oz. Bottle:  Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, cream, and a hint of hops.  Poured black in color with a tiny brown head that diminished quickly.  Opaque.  No lacing.  Flavor is medium sweet and lightly bitter.  Tastes of coffee, chocolate, roasted malts, cream, alcohol, roasting, dark fruits, and a touch of hops.  Medium body.  Tingly chalky texture is not all that smooth.  Average to lively carbonation.  Sweet, alcoholic, chalky, roasted finish.

2008 bomber.  Poured clear, very deep browh with a short-lived cap of dark tan head.  The aroma was sweet and desserty, and I really dug that.. roasted sweeter chocolates pair with lighter-roast coffee, deeper vinous fruit, and tobacco.. there was also some licorice right at the back.  The flavor had a hefty complement of burnt darker malts (semi-sweet chocolate, licorice, and coffee) along with what seemed like dry cardboardey oxidation, ash, and char.. warmer finish with a lot of coffee bitterness, charred coffee, and dark fruit.. this grew on me as the drink progressed.  Heavier-bodied with higher carbonation on the palate.. charred and warm with decent balance (some boozy, sticky licorice at the very end struck me the wrong way).. overall very solid.

Strong head, poured as dark as I would expect.  A little lacking in the nose, but the taste made up for that.  Coffee predominates, some chocolate.  A very smooth porter, the finish is quite satisfying.  One of the very best Ive had from Smutty.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2009 Re-rate, Aug 08: Bumping this sucker up, got the black patent malts for sure, tons of excellent imperial porter notes on top, well-hopped to keep this thing roasty bitter with a big rich chocolate nature. Very nicely done brew, a tad thin and milk-chocolatey on the flavor / mouthfeel, the only features that kept this from soaring on the second go-around. Yum! Bottle SL. Pour was dark brown almost black. The aroma was firm roast, strong chocolate, oats and other grains. The flavor followed the aroma, lots of robust porter notes, some faint bubblegum in the background, not sure I get all the Baltic porter notes. Mouthfeel was moderate for the style, strong roasted presence, dried up hops in the finish. Decent shot by Smutty, but not my fav of theirs.

22 oz bottle, via Dickinsonbeer.  Pours a dark brown, almost black body with a one finger fizzy brown head that fell to a partial covering.  Moderate visible carbonation.  The nose is very roasty with that classic licorice note I want in a Baltic.  Coffee, chocolate, char, minimal noticable hops.  A little nuttiness.  The flavor is much like the aroma, roasty, chocolaty, slight sweetness up front, bitter dark chocolate.  Finishes with a slight burnt chalkiness that covers the sweetness well.  Mouthfeel is full and creamy with nice soft carbonation.  Mouthcoating lingering finish with just a little warmth.  Overall, one of the best Smuttynose Ive had, I think that they nailed this one.

Poured an almost opaque black with a brown head.  Milk chocolate aroma with sweet roasted malt and a hint of ash.  The flavor was sweet and roasty.  Nice warmth with a medium body.  The CO2 was a little biting.

Very nice aroma of chocolate and coffee,  malt as well, darkest brown, small cappuccino head, some pretty lace. Taste is dark chocolate and roast coffee, medium bodied, balance and bitter. A fine treat! Thank You mds.
Black as night with a pretty good head.  Roastiness in the back of the mouth.  Coffee in the taste and aroma also alcohol.  Thich mouthful.  Some chocolate as well.

Courtesy dchmela.   Pours a burnt brown, with a craggy, light head.  The aroma is unmistakable, roasted grains, coffee, cocoa, chocolates, even a wisp of smoke.  The flavor is spot on, with the roasted malt dominating throughout, yielding slightly to allow a slight hoppy bitterness to bring this dance to a close.

Draft at Cap Ale House, post 10k recovery beer.  Pours black with a creamy tan head, very nice.  Aroma is a great blend of coffee accented malts and dark fruits.  Flavor is an almost exact match, but just exquisitely balanced, luscious, and full.  This is absolutely fantastic, an amazingly good beer.

Pours blackish brown with a thin tan head. Roasted grain, liquer sweetness, very pungent aroma. Sweet, thick, chewy, chocolate malt, hoppy taste. Very easy to drink and leaves a little roasted grain on the finish. Really solid baltic porter.

Courtesy dchmela....thanks Dave!  Pours a deep, dark chocolate brown with a small, foamy, light brown head.  A smattering of spotty lacing speckles the glass.  This is a true Baltic, as the massively malty nose clearly indicates.  Big notes of bittersweet chocolate, dark caramel, cocoa nibs, and roasted coffee mean serious business.  A mildly earthy hop character comes through a little, but make no mistake, this one is malt dominant.  The flavor is again huge and intensely roasted, with rich, smooth, chocolaty and caramelized malts.  Medium-full bodied and silky smooth, this one goes down easy and finishes with lingering roast.  This is right up there with the best that this style has to offer.  Fantastic.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours black with a large brown head that faded to a film by mid-glass and left no lacing.  The aroma was a bit odd.  While I enjoyed the malt, coffee and tobacco elements, there was a very noticable aroma of isopropyl alcohol which I did not like.  Thankfully, the rubbing alcohol was not in the flavor, which I enjoyed.  Very malty with coffee and tobacco noted as well.  Some scotch whiskey flavor emerges as the beer warms with a definite warming from the alcohol at the finish.  Except for the aroma, an enjoyable beer.

(22oz. bottle)  Pours a black body with a small tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, lactose, noticeable alcohol, some charred, and black licorice.  Flavor of roasted malt, cocoa, and light coffee with a somewhat chalky mouthfeel and dry finish.

Bottle shared with and courtesy of GregClow.  Pitch black, huge brownish head.  Great aroma featuring a ton of roast and some alcohol.  Taste features more roast - actually very little of the expected Baltic sweetness here.  But man, is that roast every tasting and integrating well with the powerful yet soothing alcohol.  Wonderful medium body that manages to be silky yet well carbonated.  Long warming alcohol finish with even more lingering roast.  Great stuff, but blind I would call this an Imperial porter and not a Baltic...

Bottle acquired from blankboy, and shared with tupalev & my lovely wife. Deep black with a large mocha head. Rich aroma of well-roasted malt, cocoa, coffee, and a bit of smoky wood. Full, silky mouthfeel. Lovely flavour with big roasty malt, espresso, dark caramel, and some dark dried fruit as it warms. Not quite as sweet as I usually expect from the style, but thats OK, it still rocks.

Bottle; dont remember the price, but it was real cheap for the size.  Poured a dark brown/black with a decent sized brown head.  Aroma of cocoa, roasted malt/barley, caramel, fruit, and earth.  Really tasty; nice blend of roasted oats, cocoa and coffee.  Hints of neat, smoke, fruit and caramel.  Palate was just ok.  Not much hop presence.  Would have liked some sweetness.
Bottle: Pours a dark brown with a tan head. Aroma, chocolate, roasted notes, caramel. Flavor, roasted notes, chocolate, dark fruits, some coffee. Pretty tasty.
Black body, small tan head, slight lacing.  Aromas of licorice, sweetness, and hops.  Flavor is dark chocolate, licorice sweetness, mild roastiness, and slight smoke.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2012 This Porter was recommended by the bartender at Capital Ale House.  It was super.  Deep black color with a brownish head.  The head dissapated.  It is a bold porter rasins and coffee flavors.  Nice finish  I will be looking for more.

long lasting caramel colored head- solid lacing on glass. aroma holds hops, malt, and slight coffee, dark chocolate, and a hint of raisins. taste expounds this, amplifying the espresso and bitter chocolate. nice mouthfeel with a good aftertaste. also ate with chocolate, very delicious.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2010 Pours motor oil black with large tan head that dissapates into a veneer. Nose of roasted barley, bitter chocolate, coffee, raisin, and hops. Upon first sip, I realized that this is one of the smoothest porters Ive ever tasted. Oily and thick, caressing the tounge and mouth. Chewy and full bodied- this beer has so much character. Chocolate, deep roasted barley, and hops all fuse together in the perfect balance to create a true masterpiece.

Bottle. Pours dark black with a brown head and good lacing. Aroma of roasted coffee, chocolate, roast, and some notes of dark fruit. flavor is creamy and smooth with roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, dark fruit, raisins, and a hint of smoke medium bodied with a slightly dry finish.  An awesome baltic porter

Pours a one finger, light brown head that goes quickly and leaves a good lace. Black as midnight. Nose is slightly malty. Light carbonation and heavy bodied. Flavor is roasted molasses. $3.99 for a 22oz bottle from Capitol Convenience Concord, NH.

Very dark brown with thick dark brown head.  Chocolatey, coffeeish nose with a slight (and rather unfortunate) phenolic note.  Hot, with a harsh astringent coffee bean note.  Unbalanced - not enough residual sugar.  More of an impy, and a crap one at that.  For one of my favourite breweries and coolest beer styles, this is a huge disappointment.

Yikes, what a great beer! On draft and very impressvie. Burnt motor oil pour with immmediate chocolate and coffee notes boomy out above a tastey thick beige head. Cocolate and slight fruit taste with a warm and wonderful mouthfeel. Yes, there is alcohol (might be only drawback on a warm spring day), but it suits the malt quite well.

Bomber. Poured black with a small tan head. Aroma of mostly chocolate and a little coffee. Mouth feel has a nice breadiness, with tastes of chocolate, coffee, dark fruits.  Seams highly carbonated which seems to bring out a slight alcohol warming in the finish. Pretty good.

22 oz. pours dark with nice size tan head. nice aroma of cocoa, coffee, and a hint of tartness. mouthful has a tangy zip with some roasted flavors peaking through. little bitter finish like dark chocolate.

2008 bomber, with a big thanks to john_adam2002!  Pours black with a moderate brownish tan head, some lacing.  Aroma has some sweet maltiness, with chocolcate syrup, espresso, milk chocolate, and ripe dark fruits.  Flavor is a bit sweet with more milk chocolate, espresso, nuts, and some dark fruit.  A nice and enjoyable baltic porter, thanks again Adam!

Thanks to McGumby for this one. A vry brown pour with a tan head and lace. A semi sweet aroma of malt. A semi sweet beer with hints of light chocoffee. Carbonation is good and palate is full. A fine baltic porter would be un understatement.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2009 Draft @ Rustico.  I seemed to really, really like this one... Huge chocolate syrup in the nose, dense roast, a little milk and cream, some sort of strange bread note.  It changes from slightly bitter bakers chocolate to a sweeter chocolate syrup flavor, very lucious and decadent, dessert-like (cake, fudge, etc) in its richness, but I was a little drunk when I had this pint, but for some reason, I just really, really dug it.

Pours a deep brown, almost black.  Ample creamy tan head.  Chocolate, roasted nuts, espresso, dried fruit in the nose.  Good body and a velvety feel in the mouth.  The flavor is milky coffee/chocolate with some notes of toasted nuts.  Nice finish.  This was good.

Draft @ Rustico.  Pours a very dark chocolate-brown color; medium tan head with solid fine-bubbled lacing.  Fair amounts of cocoa, chocolate, and some dried dark fruits in the aroma; a bit reserved and straightforward.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: tons of nougat, cocoa, and milk chocolate; creamy, dense palate, with plenty of chocolate and chewiness; still, not overly complex; lots of douginess; a touch of alcoholic warmth showing through.  Lengthy finish: cocoa, milk chocolate, and dough.

22 oz - Dense black, tan creamy head.   Rich roasted chocolate and mild coffee aromas lay upon waves of dark currants and black licorice.  Notes of lightly smoked bread surface as it warmed to room temperature.   Intense bittersweet chocolaty roast and coffee tones plow through deep hints of fig and caramel raisin.  Full bodied with smooth soft carbonation.  This easily moves to the top of my list for Smuttynose all-time favorites.  A great effort that should not be missed

First of all, I would like the thank beastiefan2k - even though I am currently enjoying this beer in the comfort of my own home, he did offer some to me at a tasting earlier this weekend, and he seemed very upset that no one was drinking it - on behalf of everyone that was there, I AM SORRY EUGENE - there were just so many great beers there that we COULDNT buy at a local store - okay, so you could have saved me 6.50, but there was Barrel-Aged Third Coast, and Pushing the Envelope Extreme, man! - how could this beer compete? - okay, so thats out of the way - this is a pretty good Baltic Porter - its heavy on the tobacco and roast, with a strong cream sweetness, and rather apparent alcohol - some notes of wood and burnt vegetation - there is an ashy/char character that clashes a bit with the high sweetness, making it a bit clumsy and out of balance, but she tastes pretty good - but once again, IM SORRY EUGENE.

Clear dark brown body with ruby highlights and a small creamy brown head. Sweet roasted malt aroma with some chocolate, caramel, and molassas. Huge sweet roasted malt flavor, lots of caramel, some chocolate and light fruity hints. Medium full body with moderately low carbonation and a smooth creamy finish.

Poured in to my 22 0z beer glass with a nice 3 inch head. Dark, oily, black appearance. I smelled coffee, chocolate, and a hint of alcohol. Bitter alcohol flavor, along with chocolate, coffee. I enjoyed it much more as I let it warm  up, became much more pleasant.I didnt notice the bottle conditioned till after the fact, but would be curious how this would be in 6 months or a year from now.

Opaque black color, beautiful creamy expresso head, lace. Chocolaty, a bit milky aroma. Very liquerish palate. Roasted, burnt malty flavors. Milky flavors like in some sweet stouts. A bit sticky finish. Smooth and balanced, although not very complex.

Bottle. Poured a nice black body with thin head. Aroma of chocolate, light hops and coffee. Flavor is chocolate, lightly bitter, pineapple, light hoppiness to it and some plums. Smooth, rich and a nice mouthfeel. This is well done.

Dark, murky, midnight black in color with a crème tan wrung around the outskirts. Aroma revels in slabs of bakers chocolate, black patent and broiled leather dipped in the grease of mocha java beans. A spongy, lactic echo fills the nostrils with loving sentiments. Flavor is ever present in true to life smutty fashion. Mocha chips and milk chocolate smeared over smoky leather straps, dangling like stalactites from the edges of the palate. Cocoa pudding sweetness and thickness in palate consistency, edging out with a hint of firewood, flame crested almonds and light accents of applewood and apple butter. Cocoa, figs and prunes and oh so smooth. Crème brulee pools of with a flame capped, crispy caramel character. Cocoa and lightly burnt cinnamon edging over caramel scones complete the classic clinic.
Bottled.  Pours cola black with a brown ring around the edges.  Smooth aroma of roasted nuts and coffee.  Same in the flavour except a slight background of menthol smoke.  Enjoyable

Shared by robert at stateline.  Color is a dark brown, decent head. Aroma is roasted malt and dried fuit.  Taste is roasted malt, toffe, caramel, small amount of hops, this beer had a little of every thing in it. Medium texture that was blended nicely together. Good beer, thanks again robert!

Pours deep onyx with 2-finger brown head.  Aroma is roasty dark malt, prunes, licorice, dry hops.  Tastes dark malty, roasty, dry, with black licorice, prune, and mild dark chocolate notes.  Defined backup hops are in the flavor, and the palate is complex and rich.  This is top notch.

Black body with a small tan head, fading. Brown sugar and raisin nose with bits of toffee, chocolate and coffee. Moderately sweet, lightly bitter taste with prunes, chocolate, caramel and a large amount of roast and doughy yeast. Full body is round with moderate carbonation. Finish is long, bitter, a bit rough and warm. Another solid effort from Smuttynose.

22 oz bomber served in my Smuttynose snifter. Pours a nice black color with ruby highlights and a 1/2" brown head. Nose is mild coffee, grains , dark fruits, & alcohol. Mouthfeel is heavy & oily. Taste is same as nose with light soy notes . There is a slight bitterness for balance. Very good effort from Smutty.

Pours black into a Stem glass.  Mocha head with good retention leaves sheet lacing as it recedes to skim surface.  Roasted pit fruit aromas.  Creamy upfront with a fizzy, lasting bitter chocolate and alcohol finish.

22oz Thanks BMartin08, Pours is a deep dark black, surprising for what i thought i was going to be drinking, smallish light brown head forms, smell is grain and dark fruits perhaps some coffee, bitter chocolate and all kinds of things.. each smell ( and i took about 10) yields something different. a very interesting smelling brew for sure... taste is of wheat/grain smooth flavor yielding to coffee and bitter chocolate, followed with some plum? and dark fruit like a belgian, this is one complex brew, and its bottle conditioned it will be interesting to see how this ages... Very Very nice though so far.

Pours an opague black body with some subtle red notes and a sticky brown foam.  The aroma is quite chocolaty with some roasted, somewhat charred malts, plums, anise, and a little alcohol.  Flavors are more milk chocolate and less bitter choc., with some earthy smoke and nuts coming through in the finish.  Some alcohol in the aftertaste but it comes off tasting more like spearmint.  Creamy, somewhat oily palate.  Really good stuff.

Draft at CB Six in Manhattan.  Poured with deep darkness and very minimal head.  Very strong aroma of roasted grain, almost coffee like (but not esspresso like).  Tasted similar to the aroma had some acidity/dryness as would be expected but the clean smooth finish complemented it nicely.

Bomber. Black, nice tan head. Big bold nose of roast, charred malts, coffee, chocolate, raisons and others. Full bodied, smooth, burnt malts, hint of smoke, expresso, lingering bitterness, dry. Damn, just a big ballsy in your face porter. Really nice as it warms past cellar.
This did its job and then some! Poured black with a creamy tan head. Lasted forever in a good way. Aroma of chocolate and coffee. Same as it smelled. Not alcohol presence what so ever. Nicely done.

Thanks to bmartin for letting me try this via trade. Pours a dark black brew allowing no light through. One finger dark brown head. The aroma is tart and fruity, anise was mentioned by those I tasted with, sweet, chocolate, coffee. The flavor showed nice coffee, roast, light fruit, some spices, warming and sweet. The palate was thick and smooth with a warming finish. Probably my second favorite baltic porter.

2008 edition. From a1 pt. 6 fl. oz (US) Big Bottle series. Pours a very dark brown with a brown, frothy head. Looks like a cream stout.  Decent brown lacing.  Aroma of cocoa and raisins.  Very creamy and bold flavor, again of cocoa and raisins with an emphasis on the latter. A slightly dry finish. Leaves a little aftertaste.  I like my porters on the smoked side and there is no smoked flavor here, which is why my rating is a tad lower than the curret average. Overall, a strong brew with a little punch to it.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2009 Dark, dark pour and foamy mocha head.  Tart aroma including notes of anise, chocolate and soy sauce.  Some coffee, maybe chicory (?) sweet chocolate, slight hop finish and some roast.  Thick, rich palate. Very easy to drink, and in some ways leaning towards a traditional English porter as much as a Baltic.  Damn good either way.

dark pour, deep tan head
roast caramel, dark fruits(dates?) in the nose
chocolate is light but full
malt is bold
dry finish
Excellent, big new beer from one of my favorite breweries
seek it out
Draft at CBsix.  Wow, a really good porter.  Pours dark and thick and taste is coffee & chox. Really good.

22oz bottle, 2008 vintage. pours pitch black with creamy tan head. nose is loaded with bakers chocolate, roast, dark fruits.  flavor is rich and smooth with bakers chocolate, dark fruits, nuts, and caramel. clean finish. alcohol very well hidden. smooth carbonation and full mouth feel. this is an awesome example of the style and stellar new beer from smuttynose.
Strong caramel and fruity malt aroma. Black color with a small brown head. Light chocolate taste that gets smoother in the finish. Creamy and slightly chalky palate.

Bottle... VBWT2008... This beer rocks!... Pitch black lager with a mid-sized, creamy, khaki-colored, everlasting head. The aroma is a swirl of rich, roasted nuts, creamed coffee and dark chocolate. Full-bodied and velvety with tingly carbonation. Chocolaty, deeply roasted, medium bitter finish. Smuttynose continues to be one of the most solid, yet least talked-about, breweries out there. This world class bottle of beer was popped open by mgumby10. Thanks for sharing!

Bottle 650ml
Appearance: Dark brown brew with neat creamy head on top.Nose :you are welcomed by soft flower aromatic hops , sweet brown malts are next in line , dry roasted mocha feel follows with touch of coco.7+Flavor/Palate : Drinking experience was bolder. Straight fast coming quality dark roasted wave, slight smoky hints. Smooth with roast, malty middle end. Alcohol was semi dry hinting that further maturing mish be beneficial. Quality was apparent but it was missing character or old Poland.14+

22 oz bottle.  I agree, this one rocks... but Smuttynose is known to be good.  Its nice to finally see some baltics making it into the arena, as Ive long known of them but not had much chance to find them.  Dark black, almost on the stout level, with a creamy off white head... it tastes as all the others have said with chocolate and smoke predominent... I like it, and will get more.

22oz bottle shared courtesy of egajdzis. 2008 vintage. Poured a deark black color with an averaged sized off whtie head. Aromas of earth, dark fruits, chocolate, roast, and light coffee. Tastes of chocolate, light roast, dark fruits, and coffee. This one was nice.

Poured an opaque brown color with a small, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, light smoke, pine, and floral hops.  Taste of more smoke, chocolate, roast, dark fruits, raisins, and vanilla, with a bit of alcohol in the finish. Creamy mouthfeel.

Draft at BT. Great burnt malt aroma with rich, quality chocolate and tons of bitterness and a sturdy head. Flavors both hoppy and roasty with dry cocoa in the finish. I hope this beer finds its way into every beer lovers hands because it FUCKIN ROCKS!
Pitch black.  Chocolate and coffee in the form of chocolate liqueur and espresso.  A distinct licorice aspect dominates in the flavor as well.  Quite good.

Near black, with what appears to be a hint of ruby. Huge thick, lasting dark khaki foam with nice lace. Tropical fruit mix with chocolate malt, hint of tar, dates, treacle, sweet espresso and light wintergreen. Aroma seems a bit green, but its quite interesting. Big sweet toasted and roasted malt flavors. Hints of lactose. As in the nose an herbal hops component. Some peat and lightly earthy coffee as well. Slick and smooth in feel. Im trying to think how it could improve in feel and I cant come up with anything. Finish is dry with some sweet licorice and tar. Linger gets sweeter with a return to some sticky malt and a touch of hops and bit of pine. Good stuff.

Pours a very dark black.  Aromas of chocolate, roast, woodsmoke, and dried fruit.  Full mouthfeel with dominant coffee flavors.  Very dry finish.  Theres an initial burst of plummy, vinuous fruit which is quickly overwhelmed by the coffee.  I cant complain too much, but I would have liked less malts and more of the fruit.  Still, an exceptional porter.  One of my favorite styles.

22 oz bottle.  Rich unfiltered black beer.  Thick dark brownish head.  The aroma is quite authentic initially, sweet salty roasted barley, dark chocolate and a bittersweet toasted character.  Behind the sweet/toasted malt character is a fairly distracting DMS-like cooked vegetable flavour.  Otherwise, it is rich and chocolatey with a lot of bitter chocolate, salted roast and soft lean malts.  Some coffeeish flavour on the back.  Its got some very good points about it, but there are also some serious flaws.
Wow! poured jet black with a nice tan frothy head. Notes of coffee,mocha,and roasted malt. Coats your mouth and is very drinkable. Much better then Victorys baltic imo.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Courtesy mgumby10. Pours pitch black, with a watery and slightly creamy tan head. Nice lacing. Aroma is roasted espresso and sweet chocolate. I like where this is going. Roasted malts, warming chocolate, and some slight alcohol. Surprisingly a bit thin-bodied. Like this one a lot.

22 oz. brown bomber. No freshness date seen. Slightly contaminated. Produced a gusher when opened. Poured (gushed more like it) out a deep chocolate brown, with a huge tan head. Over carbonated to the max.
Aromas are licorice & not much else. Burnt malts in the flavors. Not that good a beer. Maybe Ill re-rate it when I can find an uncontaminated bottle.

Courtesy Dickinsonbeer.  Thanks Paul!  Pours black, with a creamy off white head.  Smells of big roasty toasted malts, with a lighter chocolate influence.  Smells pretty inviting.  The flavor is much of th same, as the roasty malts and nuts make up most of its flavor characters.  The chocolate was there for moral support.  Very nicely balanced, great flavor.  Had a touch of some coffee in there too.  Another great offering from Smutty.

Bomber bottle from Brent and enjoyed in my Stone IRS snifter: Opaque with a fading tan creamy head and left spotty lace in its wake. The aroma has notes of charred and chocolate malt, plum and star fruit, molasses and liquorice, coffee and herbal hops, REALLY NICE !!

The taste starts with ultra rich malting over a fruity twang supported by some hop and coffee bitterness. Some smoke and earthy qualities on the finish. The mouth feel is lush and oily with just enough carbonation to keep ya very interested, dry and ashy finish. WOW, What a powerhouse and very well attenuated, a beautiful sipping beer and a must try for any stoutie.
22 oz bomber  jet black pour , thick off white head. aroma of coffee and/or expresso. flavor is chocolate malt , dark fruit , coffee beans , and licorice . roasty , chewy , dry and creamy . excellent

On tap @ Coles Buffalo NY. Pours a deep black. Medium body with ligfht to medium oily mouthfeel. Coffee, anise flavors. Leaves a strange bitterness on tip of your tongue. pretty good but prefer thre Robust porter

Deep pitch black coloured body, 100% opaque with a thick tan head. Aroma of deep roasted coffee, bittersweet chocolate and strong pit fruits...but of course some roasted malt is tucked in there too. Full-bodied; Super chewy mouthful that doesnt start pleasant - very meaty and mushroomy flavours start out the taste, coupled with roasted malt, nuts and some sweetness of deep pit fruits. Aftertaste shows some cherries, chocolate and even more meaty and savoury tastes. Overall, a decent - but too strong and too meaty flavour. Still worth trying, but Ive had many other baltic porters that were better than this one. I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased from Whole Foods in Arlington (Clarendon), Virginia on 9-February-2008.

22 oz bomber.  Pours a thick oily black with a thick creamy light brown head.  Aroma of roasted coffee beans and malt, black licorice and chocolate.  Taste is creamy and smooth with a malty presence and hints of roasted coffee beans, black licorice and dark chocolate.  Excellent !!

Bomber.  Pours a nice deep dark almsot black with a nice thin lasting tan head.  Aroma is green, earthy and herbal hops- typical smutty- similar to the impy stout aroma- but with nice chocolate malts  but also some greet acetaldehyde- too new?  Chocolate and nuts in the flavor, a bit of tar, licorice, and anise- bitter hoppy and dark chocolate finish- phenolic and a touch of yeast.  Relatively smooth overall- although I get a bit of alcohol as it warms.  Pretty good overall- but a bit young and very green (hoopy, new and acetaldehyde).

Pours viscous black with less than a finger of tan head.  Aroma of coffee, dark chocolate, raisin, and dark fruit.  Flavor contains largely coffee notes up front, complemented by dark chocolate in the middle, and raisin, fig, licorice, and slight hop bitterness  at the end.  Fairly thick and creamy body finishes slightly dry.  One of the better Baltics Ive had the pleasure of consuming.

Shared by Dickinsonbeer. Just about opaque black in color with a creamy brown head.  Aroma: Chocolate, and heavily roasted malt, light hints of ash.  Taste is alot of chocolate, and roasted malt with a big moderately sweet creamy body.  Very smooth- finishes with some lightly acrid, bitter roasted grain.  Thought this was great.

Malty sweet with a lot of chocolate and roast in the flavor and aroma. The mouthfeel is incredibly creamy and velvety. Much more body than I anticipated. No trace of alcohol. A pleasure to drink. One of their best.

Pours thick black like motor oil into the English pint glass with a fluffy two inch tan head.  Heavy espresso-like aromas with some notes of malt and chocolate.  A very robust flavor with a heavy rush of chocolate chips, malt and coffee.  A very thick, coating mouthfeel with a bitter, dry finish.  Very enjoyable.

Pours opaque black, with a tan head of a half-inch. The tightly packed foam settled quickly and dissapated to a partial skim-coat, and eventually to several errant whisps.
Aromatics are laced with acrid malt, bitter chocolate, spent coffee grounds, and powdered nougat. Quite dry and roasty in the nose.
The mouthfeel is full, chewy, and very creamy.
The pallet is filled with heavily roasted malt, singed chocolate bits, and burnt bread ends.
Warming alcohol follows through along with hints of black licorice and lingering dark caramel.
Bitterness is smooth and balancing, and other hopping is subdued. Fruity esters are no-where to be found.
Finishes very dry, somewhat acrid, and a bit grainy.

I can see this becoming a crushed velvet tongue tickler after a couple of years in the cellar.
